    <item>
      <title>The Stone Roses: All For One review – lacking the stardust of the band's peak</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/the-stone-roses-all-for-one-review</link>
      <description><p>The Manchester band’s first music in 21 years will please the faithful, but those who crave the group’s true magic are unlikely to feel fulfilled </p><p>The message from the band wasn’t exactly overflowing with detail: “The Stone Roses will release a new single tonight at 8pm,” it said. Well, they always could be a bit terse.</p><p>Yet it said enough. After the Twitter rumours, <a href="http://www.nme.com/blogs/nme-blogs/the-stone-roses-is-the-third-coming-on-the-horizon">the snaps of band members hurriedly entering Paul Epworth’s north London recording studio</a> and a series of lemon posters erected in their hometown of Manchester, we’re finally here: All For One is the first new material from the Stone Roses in 21 years. And on paper, it has plenty of Roses touchstones: psychedelic vocals, a brilliant Squire solo that doesn’t overstay its welcome and a lyrical theme of solidarity – “All for one, one for all/If we all join hands we’ll make a wall” – that harks back to their rave roots. It’s surprisingly rocking – Reni’s drums flinging it along at a frantic, clattering pace – and the chorus will be bellowed loudly in fields by many a middle-aged man this summer.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/the-stone-roses-all-for-one-review">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Macklemore and Ryan Lewis: ‘Systemic racism isn’t going to get clicks’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/macklemore-ryan-lewis-systemic-racism-isnt-going-get-clicks</link>
      <description><p>Unrest in Ferguson led the duo to question their role in hip-hop. The result was White Privilege II, an examination of how white people view race. Will the pair’s soul-searching make fans assess their place in society, too?</p><p>The first sound recorded during this interview with Ben “Macklemore” Haggerty and Ryan Lewis tells you a lot about where their heads are right now. Before a word has been spoken, Haggerty lets out a cavernous yawn, one that threatens never to end. “Tired?” I ask as he slumps in front of me in a room backstage at the O2 in London. He nods&nbsp;back, the energy for words still beyond him.</p><p>There are obvious reasons why Haggerty might be knackered. He is currently six&nbsp;months into a world tour promoting the duo’s second studio album, This Unruly Mess I’ve Made, a tour which, if tonight’s show is anything to go by, requires every ounce of energy he can conserve: just over an hour from now, he will be performing slam-dunk leaps across the stage for the venue’s 10,000-strong crowd. Haggerty also recently became a father for the first time, a calling to which he is so determined to give his all that this morning he got up early and took his daughter Sloane on a tour of London.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/macklemore-ryan-lewis-systemic-racism-isnt-going-get-clicks">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Margo Price: ‘Country music is about divorce, drinking and jail’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/margo-price-country-music-is-about-divorce-drinking-and-jail</link>
      <description><p>The outlaw Nashville singer worried she’d be singing to empty bars her whole life until Jack White heard the songs on Midwest Farmer’s Daughter</p><p>A new sticker has appeared on the back of the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2014/jul/23/jack-white-third-man-records-books-publishing-wing">Third Man Records</a> minivan, which is blocking the driveway of Margo Price’s home in Inglewood, East Nashville: “You puke, you pay!”</p><p>“I don’t know if it’s for us or another band,” the 33-year-old singer says, before apologising profusely. She drove back from a show at 3am the night before so she could be home when her five-year-old son Judah woke up this morning. She’s lost her voice, hasn’t slept a full night in weeks, and her grass is so overgrown that it broke the lawnmower. Her car is littered with the debris of a fishing trip, which she quickly tidies away.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/margo-price-country-music-is-about-divorce-drinking-and-jail">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Skepta: Konnichiwa review – rhymes that are dextrous, sharp and very British</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/skepta-konnichiwa-review-boy-better-know-album-of-the-week</link>
      <description><p>The architect of grime’s resurgence might have an eye on the US market, but he’s a distinctively, winningly English rapper<br></p><p>It features five singles – two of them silver-certified hits – guest appearances from A$AP Mob’s Young Lord and A$AP Nast and a collaboration with Pharrell Williams, but the most telling track on <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/06/10-things-we-learned-from-skeptas-konnichiwa">Skepta’s fourth album</a> might well be one that contains no music at all. As a tense bit of old-fashioned grime called Corn on the Curb unexpectedly ends – Skepta apparently forgetting the lyrics midway through a line, the sparse musical backing grinding to a halt – it’s replaced by the sound of a phone call between Skepta and fellow rapper Chip. The former sounds despondent, which comes as something of a surprise.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2015/dec/21/shutdown-skepta-best-track-of-2015-grime">The best track of 2015: Shutdown by Skepta</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/skepta-konnichiwa-review-boy-better-know-album-of-the-week">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Rick Astley: ‘I made tea for Bananarama, Dead or Alive, Mel and Kim’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/rick-astley-i-made-tea-for-bananarama-dead-or-alive-mel-and-kim</link>
      <description><p>After perfecting the art of brewing hot drinks in a studio, pop legend Astley retired at 27. But how much did he make from rickrolling?</p><p><strong>Hi Rick! What’s it like to retire in your 20s (1) ?</strong></p><p>It’s a bit weird. I hadn’t had a proper job – I haven’t had a normal life, really. And I’m very grateful for that. The idea of stopping at 27 and saying, “I’m not going to do that any more,” was strange. There was a period of sitting around a lot doing bugger all, but very quickly I had a studio built. I was going to try and be a songwriter and producer for other people. Managers and A&amp;R people would send singers round and I’d think, “This person has got great hair, but they can’t actually sing.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/rick-astley-i-made-tea-for-bananarama-dead-or-alive-mel-and-kim">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Manic Street Preachers release their Euro 2016 song Together Stronger</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/manic-street-preachers-release-their-euro-2016-song-together-stronger</link>
      <description><p>The Manics have released their official song for the Welsh national team. Former Scotland striker Joe Jordan – a villain to Welsh fans for nearly 40 years – should cover his ears</p><p>The Manic Street Preachers have finally revealed their official Euro 2016 anthem for the Wales national team, Together Stronger (C’mon Wales).</p><p>The song, with a video featuring the Wales football squad pogoing along behind the band, pays tribute to the former Wales player and manager Gary Speed, gripes about Joe Jordan’s handball playing for Scotland against Wales in a decisive qualifying match for the 1978 World Cup finals, and namechecks large chunks of the current squad, with special attention paid in the chorus to Gareth Bale and Aaron Ramsey.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/manic-street-preachers-release-their-euro-2016-song-together-stronger">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Share your recommendations in the comments and our reader will pick the best eligible songs in a playlist next week<br></p><p>This week we want to hear your songs on the theme of power.     <item>
      <title>Marshall Marcus: The European Union Youth Orchestra cannot be strangled by European bureaucracy</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/13/marshall-marcus-the-european-union-youth-orchestra-cannot-be-strangled</link>
      <description><p>The EUYO has announced its closure. Chief Executive Marshall Marcus explains why a 40-year-old institution that represents the best of pan-European creativity has been silenced</p><p>Amid the sagging plethora of Brexit conversations, real passion can often seem to be lacking among the EU’s top brass. Except however, when they talk about one particular enterprise: “<a href="http://www.euyo.eu/">The European Union Youth Orchestra</a> remains one of our most distinguished ambassadors … a potent symbol of our European Union.” (<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/jean-claude-juncker">Jean-Claude Juncker</a>, EU Commission President). <br></p><p>“I was moved not simply by the beauty of the music they produced, but also by what they stand for: the EUYO perfectly embodies the power of being united in diversity,” (Juncker’s colleague <a href="http://www.europarl.europa.eu/the-president/en/">Martin Schulz</a>, European Parliament President). </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/13/marshall-marcus-the-european-union-youth-orchestra-cannot-be-strangled">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>It’s not meant to end like this, Ozzy. You’re the Prince of Darkness</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/lostinshowbiz/2016/may/13/sharon-ozzy-osbourne-divorce-hairdresser</link>
      <description><p>Ozzy Osbourne’s alleged affair with his hairdresser – and the way that Sharon rumbled him – is enough to shake your faith in love, marriage – and even reality TV<br><br></p><p>You can never accuse Ozzy and Sharon Osbourne of dodging the zeitgeist. If popular culture is celebrating something – be it heavy metal or reality TV or Louis Walsh’s big, dumb, competition-winner of a face – you can guarantee that you’ll find the Osbournes somewhere in the foreground, clattering into each other like wasps in a jar.</p><p>With this in mind, it should come as no surprise that they are at it again. Because this is 2016, a year culturally identified by beautiful unions in states of deep internal crisis. There was Jay Z and Beyoncé. There was Batman and Superman. And now, inevitably, there is <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/10/ozzy-osbourne-marriage-end-sober-drugs">Ozzy and Sharon Osbourne</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/lostinshowbiz/2016/may/13/sharon-ozzy-osbourne-divorce-hairdresser">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Azealia Banks suspended from Twitter following racist attack on Zayn Malik</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/azealia-banks-suspended-twitter-racist-rant-zayn-malik</link>
      <description><p>The rapper’s latest Twitter feud saw her strike out at former One Direction star Malik with homophobic and racially charged slurs</p><p>Rapper <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/azealia-banks">Azealia Banks</a> has been suspended from Twitter following a series of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/11/azealia-banks-axed-uk-music-festival-zayn-malik-twitter">racially charged tweets</a> attacking singer and former One Direction star Zayn Malik.</p><p>After Banks accused Malik of copying a music video of hers for his single Like I Would, Malik tweeted “My @’s too good for you” – a reference to the fact that Banks had not directed the accusation at his account for him to see.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/azealia-banks-suspended-twitter-racist-rant-zayn-malik">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Jessy Lanza: Oh No review – wonky pop, peak danceability</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/jessy-lanza-oh-no-review-wonky-pop-peak-danceability</link>
      <description><p>(Hyperdub)</p><p>When Canada’s <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/jul/24/jessy-lanza-r-and-b-singer">Jessy Lanza</a> debuted with 2013’s Pull My Hair Back, she was <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/aug/15/timbaland-future-stars-experimental-cassie">pigeonholed</a> as one of the “future R&amp;B” artists mixing up 90s sounds with new electronics. Understandably, she and co-producer/husband Jeremy Greenspan have made a run for it on second album Oh No and a wider – and weirder – range of influences, from <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2004/jan/09/popandrock.shopping1">Yellow Magic Orchestra </a>and J-pop to Chicago footwork and New Orleans bounce, shine through their wonky pop prism. Lanza’s smoky sensuality is still there on slow jams such as Begins, Could Be You and I Talk BB, which recalls one of Prince’s syrupiest piano moments. But much of it is, brilliantly, like something from a dusty Dance Mania tape, recognisable only by Lanza’s distinct, vapour-light voice. At times, the production can be overly fussy (see Going Somewhere), but tracks such as VV Violence (squelchy electro-funk by way of girlish electroclash) and Never Enough (a nod to smooth house dude <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/oct/26/dj-morgan-geist-favourite-tracks">Morgan Geist</a>) demonstrate their ability to team that experimentalism with peak-time danceability. There could be a bona fide pop star in Jessy Lanza yet.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/jessy-lanza-oh-no-review-wonky-pop-peak-danceability">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Twin Peaks: Down in Heaven review – exuberant garage rock refuses to grow up</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/twin-peaks-down-heaven-review-pop-cd-review-grand-jury</link>
      <description><p>(Grand Jury)</p><p><a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2014/jul/30/10-of-the-best-garage-punk">Garage rock</a> has long been affixed to adolescence. Not only was its raucous sound supposedly hammered out in the outbuildings of parental residences, but it was also founded during pop’s own coming of age. This third album by <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2014/may/30/twin-peaks">Chicago band Twin Peaks</a> shows it’s a genre that continues to bristle with frustrated feeling and arrested development. On Cold Lips, childishly cruel character assassinations (“All there is in you is an absence of space”) are croaked over sharp, bright guitars, while Wanted You steals a refrain from <a draggable="true" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eDVkkwl6aJo">John Lennon’s Mother</a> and puts it to less Freudian, more moany ends. It means that, despite this being a record that speaks pretty explicitly to 40-odd years ago (the most obvious comparison would be to a loafing Rolling Stones, although at times the band sound slightly like a het-up Lemonheads), the clattering exuberance of both the sentiment and the sound means it feels far from stale. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/twin-peaks-down-heaven-review-pop-cd-review-grand-jury">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Corinne Bailey Rae: The Heart Speaks in Whispers review – sweet, smooth soul</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/corinne-bailey-rae-the-heart-speaks-in-whispers-review-cd-pop-virgin</link>
      <description><p>(Virgin)</p><p><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/10/corinne-bailey-rae-live-review-tabernacle-london">Corinne Bailey Rae</a>’s last album, 2010’s <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2010/jan/28/corinne-bailey-rae-the-sea">The Sea</a>, was a grief-stricken affair that dealt with the death of her first husband. Time has been a healer, and this follow-up documents the storm breaking and light emerging into Bailey Rae’s life and lyrics: “Like seeing the sun again, after years of pouring rain,” she sings on standout track Caramel. Bailey Rae’s adoration of classic soul can be both a blessing and a curse. Do You Ever Think of Me, with its shifting chords and sweet falsetto peaks, treads a little too closely to <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2015/aug/05/curtis-mayfield-10-best-soul-funk">Curtis Mayfield</a>’s The Makings of You for comfort, and other tracks tend to drift so smoothly they can pass you by. But on Caramel, her soulful vocals are given space to bloom over a billowing pop backdrop. And with the likes of Frank Ocean and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/jun/21/kendrick-lamar-interview-to-pimp-a-butterfly-trayvon-martin">Kendrick Lamar</a> reviving jazzy, 70s psych-soul, the laidback approach Bailey Rae takes on tracks such as Been to the Moon sounds perfectly in keeping with the times. <br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/corinne-bailey-rae-the-heart-speaks-in-whispers-review-cd-pop-virgin">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Kygo: Cloud Nine review – tropical house by committee</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/kygo-cloud-nine-review</link>
      <description><p>(Sony)</p><p>Norwegian producer Kygo has accrued more than a billion streams on Spotify ahead of his debut LP, partly via irresistible banger <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9Sc-ir2UwGU">Firestone</a> – the urtext for tropical house. This success has secured a lobotomised brains trust of neo-MOR singers, weaving grimly competent songwriting through Kygo’s catchy backings, where flutes and pianos form neatly resolving ringtones. <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2014/feb/11/tom-odell-live-review">Tom Odell</a> gives Fiction some bright falsetto, but is torpedoed by a ghastly honky-tonk melody ripped from Avicii’s playbook; <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/mar/08/john-legend-adds-lyrics-downton-abbey-theme-jimmy-kimmel">John Legend</a> should be ashamed of Happy Birthday, which sounds like it was commissioned for the sweet 16 of a kleptocrat’s daughter. And with <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/aug/02/foxes-live-review">Foxes</a> finding herself sinking in quicksand and lost in a desert, the lyrics are as earnest and emotionally inarticulate as a 19-year-old on Tinder. Well, this is pop, where cliche can be transcendent, but these joyless songs are chemically castrated of any passion or sexuality. It falls to – ahem – <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/feb/05/kodaline-coming-up-for-air-review">Kodaline</a> to conjure the keenest feeling, on the laughably titled Raging. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/kygo-cloud-nine-review">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Meghan Trainor: Thank You review – dance pop hurtles into romantic mush</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/meghan-trainor-thank-you-review-pop</link>
      <description><p>(Sony)</p><p>After the mega-selling All About That Bass, <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2014/oct/02/meghan-trainor-all-about-that-bass-interview-im-getting-flak">Meghan Trainor</a>’s second major-label album is supposedly influenced by Elvis, Aretha Franklin and, er, <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/may/05/olly-murs-review-o2-arena-london">Olly Murs</a>. One can imagine the King purring the acoustic Just a Friend in one of his bad films, but there’s lots of trademark Trainor: butt-wobbling, retro R&amp;B and ostensible female-empowerment anthems that on closer inspection pander to the male gaze. In Woman Up – a reworking of <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/lostinshowbiz/2014/jul/17/ashley-roberts-pussycat-dolls-hugging-guru-amma">Ashley Roberts</a>’ 2014 flop, by the same writing-production team – the 22-year-old suggests, “Put your favourite heels on, ’cos they make you feel strong.” On her recent hit <a draggable="true" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cMTAUr3Nm6I">No</a> she rebuts unwanted male advances with a swing of her hips. Contradictions abound as dance pop hurtles into Caribbean flavours and romantic mush. The funky I Love Me is a bit self-help-manual-with-beats, but Trainor sounds joyously empowered. Ultimately, much of Thank You is a bit of a hotchpotch, after her initial efforts were rejected and main <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/may/18/ricky-reed-music-producer-wallpaper">producer Ricky Reed</a> called on to conjure up some hits.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/meghan-trainor-thank-you-review-pop">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>LCD Soundsystem – 10 of the best</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2016/may/11/lcd-soundsystem-10-of-the-best-james-murphy</link>
      <description><p>James Murphy’s pioneering dance-punk project began with him singing about midlife crises. Yet they were always ready to fill the dancefloor, too<br></p><p>“I’m losing my edge / the kids are coming up from behind,” half-mutters James Murphy, for the opening lyrics of the first track he released as LCD Soundsystem. Over the next four minutes he both predicted the shape of his own career and deflected many of the criticisms that might be levelled at it; that he’s a middle-aged hipster with an overstuffed record bag into which he’s only too happy to dive. He’s admitting every charge against him, but qualifying his admission: “Don’t I have great taste?” Losing My Edge was released in 2002 on a wave of rising hype for Murphy. After co-producing David Holmes’ raw-sounding 2000 album Bow Down to the Exit Sign, he and former UNKLE member Tim Goldsworthy joined Jonathan Galkin in forming DFA Records, scoring an early, scuzzy hipster hit with the Rapture’s <a draggable="true" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6HP04nfUi4g">House of Jealous Lovers</a>. Recorded with longstanding collaborator Nancy Whang and Spank Rock’s Alex Epton, Losing My Edge was meant to be a one-off, a reaction – as he told journalist John Doran at the time – to the fear he felt that being “the cool rock disco guy” would come to a crashing end. “It became a wider thing about people who grip on to other people’s creations like they are their own,” he said, reflecting on his own DJ career. “There is a lot of pathos in that character, though, because it’s born out of inadequacy and love.” The lyric begins amid comedy, as Murphy haughtily proclaims over a skipping drum machine beat that he was at every key moment in the birth of western underground music, and ends in distorted euphoria as he bellows a litany of his key influences, from Todd Terry to Joy Division and Sun Ra to “<a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2008/mar/24/popandrock">the Sonics</a>! The Sonics! The Sonics! The Sonics!” It was some calling card.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2016/may/11/lcd-soundsystem-10-of-the-best-james-murphy">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/lcd-soundsystem">LCD Soundsystem</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/music">Music</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/popandrock">Pop and rock</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/electronicmusic">Electronic music</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/dance-music">Dance music</category>

    <item>
      <title>Declan McKenna – the story behind Paracetamol</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2016/may/11/declan-mckenna-the-story-behind-paracetamol</link>
      <description><p>The young musician tells of how the death of Leelah Alcorn, a transgender teen from Ohio, spurred a flurry of songwriting he hopes will encourage people to care</p><p>I’m 17 now. I wrote Paracetamol between the ages of 15 and 16. With many of my songs, I have this strange habit of spending months fumbling over song structure ideas before suddenly writing all the lyrics in one day, and that’s what happened here. What sparked that flurry was a story I read about a transgender girl called <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/society/2015/apr/29/trangender-teenager-leelah-alcorn-ohio-suicide">Leelah Alcorn who committed suicide in December 2014</a>. Her mother told her she would never be a girl, and she had been compelled to undergo Christian transgender “conversion” therapy.</p><p>It was a disgusting story. Not only must it have been a truly horrific experience for Leelah, but knowing that this wasn’t an isolated case genuinely terrified me. <br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2016/may/11/declan-mckenna-the-story-behind-paracetamol">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Pet Shop Boys' new video proves they're the ultimate singles band</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2016/may/10/pet-shop-boys-twenty-something-new-video</link>
      <description><p>We’re premiering the video for Pet Shop Boys’ new single Twenty-something. Why should you care? Because they’re the masters of the one-track masterpiece</p><p>Call a group a “singles band” still and it feels like a barb. Perhaps it’s because singles began life as cynical, commerce-boosting products, and that legacy has lingered (“The new 7in record ensures you greater profit through faster turnover!” crowed RCA, so romantically, at the format’s launch in 1949). The album has long been seen as the ultimate expression of cleverness, too, forgetting that big ideas are often more powerful when they’re conveyed in short, sharp shocks. As <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1IZ4gTzSmhY">one suburban sage</a> said – <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=__RdJtpmIZE">someone whom the Pet Shop Boys would cover</a> – “we learned more from a three-minute record, baby, than we ever learned in school”.<br></p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/mar/18/pet-shop-boys-academic-symposium">Party conference: why the Pet Shop Boys are worthy of academic consideration</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2016/may/10/pet-shop-boys-twenty-something-new-video">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2016/may/06/basement-jaxx-playlist-arbeid-adelt-fast-eddie-dj-pierre-black-magic</link>
      <description><p>Simon Ratcliffe reveals his old-school favourites – and recalls the time-bending thrills of the dance-pop duo’s early days</p><p>I came across this on a Maurice Fulton mixtape and managed to track a copy down. It’s from Belgium, dated back to the 1980s, and is a mixture of electro, punk and funk. It really feels as if it’s from a period in music where anything goes – a new movement is forming but templates or rules have not yet been written. It’s got a killer electronic bass line and it sounds as if they’re just having an electronic jam session. I love how spontaneous and raw it is.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2016/may/06/basement-jaxx-playlist-arbeid-adelt-fast-eddie-dj-pierre-black-magic">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Fela Kuti – 10 of the best</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2016/may/05/fela-kuti-10-best-songs</link>
      <description><p>A look back over a seminal career that encompassed political dissidence, UFO contact, chicken sacrifice – and some of the greatest dance music ever recorded</p><p>Olufela Olusegun Oludotun Ransome-Kuti was born on 15 October 1938 in Abeokuta, Nigeria to influential upper middle-class parents. His mother was one of Nigeria’s leading feminists and a prominent anti-colonial protester while his father, a preacher, was the first president of the Nigerian Union of Teachers. They planned careers in medicine for their three sons (and Olikoye Ransome-Kuti would go on to become the Nigerian health minister) but Fela, a rebel from the outset, switched courses within days of arriving in London to study. While he was attending Trinity College of Music between 1958 and 1961 he formed the Koola Lobitos. He led this highlife-influenced jazz band, as a trumpet player, taking full advantage of the underground London craze for African dance music in the 1960s.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2016/may/05/fela-kuti-10-best-songs">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/05/readers-recommend-playlist-songs-about-spying</link>
      <description><p>There’s a sinister subterfuge running through the playlist this week, with artists from Bauhaus to King Creosote collected by a reader on a mission<br></p><p><em>Below is this week’s playlist – picked by a reader from the comments on <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/28/readers-recommend-share-your-songs-about-spying">last week’s blog</a>. Thanks for your suggestions. Read more about the weekly format of the Readers recommend series at the end of the piece.</em></p><p>I had no idea what was expected from me as I turned up for duty <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/28/readers-recommend-share-your-songs-about-spying">on Thursday</a> armed only with enthusiasm and a clear weekend ahead of me. “You’re to track down spies, round up 12 of the best and send them to my office by Wednesday morning,” I was told. <br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/05/readers-recommend-playlist-songs-about-spying">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>As the Supergrass founder launches his latest project under new moniker <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vc7nTH0kcZI">Vangoffey</a>, he selects five of his most played tracks</p><p>I love <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/oct/16/elliott-smith-rocks-backpages">Elliott Smith</a>.     <item>
      <title>Motörhead's Bomber – watch an exclusive track from Lemmy's last tour</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/29/motorhead-lemmy-kilminster-bomber-clean-your-clock-munich</link>
      <description><p>See exclusive footage of the metal group performing live at the Zenith in Munich – their last recorded gig – from upcoming release Clean Your Clock</p><p>Up until his death in December 2015, Lemmy Kilmister continued to front those thunderous titans of rock’n’roll, Motörhead. “For as long as I can walk the few yards from the back to the front of the stage without a stick,” <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/aug/13/lemmy-apparently-i-am-still-indestructible-motorhead-album-bad-magic">he told the Guardian</a> in August last year. “Or even if I do have to use a stick.”</p><p>In November 2015, UDR Records made the decision to record Motörhead’s two sold-out shows at the Zenith in Munich, Germany; footage that would turn out out to be the last documentation of the group performing live. Following <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/lemmy">Lemmy</a>’s death on 28 December, two days after he was diagnosed with an extremely aggressive cancer, drummer <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/dec/31/drummer-mikkey-dee-says-motorhead-is-over-after-lemmys-death">Mikkey Dee</a> confirmed that without their frontman and bassist, the band would no longer continue.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/29/motorhead-lemmy-kilminster-bomber-clean-your-clock-munich">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/motorhead">Motorhead</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/music">Music</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/culture">Culture</category>

      <title>Lush's playlist: Peppermint Rainbow, Brett Smiley and more</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/02/lush-playlist-peppermint-rainbow-brett-smiley</link>
      <description><p>The shoegazers’ bassist Phil King discusses sunshine pop, French rock’n’roll and partying with Eddie Izzard</p><p> Henry is my drinking buddy. If I post a photo on Instagram of the area by the Thames near where he lives, my friends say: “Uh oh!” He is a bit of a genius. He also has an EMS suitcase Synthi (bought from David Vorhaus of White Noise. Brian Eno also has one) and after a few drinks he will play the opening synth noises to <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IfniG-AdSC4">Hawkwind’s Silver Machine</a> on it. He shared the same manager as the Police and Miles Copeland, who got him a major deal with A&amp;M in the late 70s, and recorded an album that disappeared without trace. It’s been described as “Syd Barrett produced by Brian Eno”. I hope someone reissues it. It’s brilliant.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/02/lush-playlist-peppermint-rainbow-brett-smiley">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>True Colors review – Kesha is back in defiant anthem</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/29/kesha-true-colors-review-zedd</link>
      <description><p>‘I won’t apologize for the fire in my eyes,’ sings the embattled pop star in her anthemic new collaboration with EDM star Zedd </p><p>“I’m not afraid,” Kesha declares in True Colors, her first song in three years. Not to be confused with Cyndi Lauper’s 80s classic, True Colors is less danceable than Kesha’s last single, Timber, her 2013 collaboration with Pitbull – but it’s no less addictive.</p><p>First debuted at Coachella with EDM artist Zedd, True Colors finds the pop star in an urgent and defiant mood. Given all that’s transpired since Kesha brought a lawsuit against her former mentor for sexual assault in 2014 (most <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/apr/06/judge-dismisses-keshas-sexual-assault-case-against-producer-dr-luke">recently</a>, a judge in New York dismissed her case), the tone couldn’t be more appropriate. Consider True Colors her #FreeKesha anthem.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/29/kesha-true-colors-review-zedd">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>J Dilla – 10 of the best</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2016/apr/27/j-dilla-10-of-the-best</link>
      <description><p>In a short career, the Detroit rapper cemented a reputation as a cult great with underground strip-club jams, Beatles-inspired psychedelia and joyous neo-soul</p><p>By the time Jay Dee – whose real name was James Yancey – became J Dilla, he had made a reputation for himself by producing albums for Common, the Pharcyde and A Tribe Called Quest, among others. With his debut solo album Welcome 2 Detroit, he switched up his style, broadening his range to combine world music, live instrumentation and German electronica with grimy hip hop, despite his original intention to make a breakbeat record. Welcome 2 Detroit is a primer on Dilla’s home city, exemplified by the lead single, Pause. If you subtract his grunt and ad-lib at the start, Dilla’s presence is mainly revealed in the composition and production, allowing underground talents Frank-N-Dank to take centre stage. Springing from a stutter-step rhythm and Dilla’s soupy beats, Frank runs through each letter of their name while Dank spits braggadocio-laden verses as a marker for their brand. Always running ahead of the pack, Pause is a proto-snap, strip-club jam that predicts the subgenre’s prevalence in the years that followed.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2016/apr/27/j-dilla-10-of-the-best">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Tony Conrad: five of the best moments by Dream Syndicate drone pioneer</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/12/tony-conrad-five-of-the-best-moments-dream-syndicate-drone-pioneer</link>
      <description><p>The legendary composer, musician, artist, professor and film-maker has died on Saturday aged 76. From his voluminous five-decade body of work, here are some of his best pieces of drone rock and experimental film </p><p> It’s hard to find many recordings of the Theatre of Eternal Music, sometimes known as the Dream Syndicate – a 1960s supergroup that featured Conrad, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/jan/17/john-cale-interview-music-for-a-new-society-lou-reed-david-bowie">John Cale</a>, La Monte Young, Marian Zazeela, Angus MacLise, and sometimes Terry Jennings and others – for a complicated snarl of reasons, not least because it was so revolutionary at the time. “We made the first drone music,” <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/mar/22/people-thought-we-were-on-drugs-and-we-were-tony-conrad-the-great-avant-garde-adventurer">Conrad told the Guardian</a> earlier this year. “No! I would say the first non-bagpipe, western drone music. But because people hadn’t heard this sort of thing, it was regarded with scepticism. Some people thought we were crazy, some people thought we were high on drugs.” </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/12/tony-conrad-five-of-the-best-moments-dream-syndicate-drone-pioneer">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Bibio's playlist: Don Blackman, John Coltrane and Johnny Hartman, and more</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/11/bibio-uk-producer-playlist-don-blackman-john-coltrane-johnny-hartman-change</link>
      <description><p>UK producer’s music of the moment includes 80s boogie, Icelandic jazz, a little-known vocalist whose voice is ‘made of oak’ and a film gem</p><p>My friend Rob Lee (of <a href="https://soundcloud.com/waxstag">Wax Stag</a>) put on The Box Tree one night when I went to stay with him. I remember it being the perfect choice at the time, even though I’d never heard it before. Sometime later I bought the album, twice in fact because I loved it so much I had to get it on vinyl too. I’ve never heard anything quite like this track, it’s labelled as jazz but I don’t hear it as jazz. What I hear is unique, mysterious; the intriguing and magical side of bleak, like a misty forest in a strange land. I’ve never been to Iceland, but I can’t help thinking only Icelandic people could make music with this specific vibe. I drift into another world in my mind when I listen to this.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/11/bibio-uk-producer-playlist-don-blackman-john-coltrane-johnny-hartman-change">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Thomas Cohen's playlist: Laura Nyro, Kate & Anna McGarrigle and more</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/08/thomas-cohen-playlist-laura-nyro-kate-anna-mcgarrigle-alain-goraguer</link>
      <description><p>The singer-songwriter chooses some of his favourite German jazz, 70s folk music and French soundtrack cuts</p><p>I found out about Judee Sill through the Radio 4 show <a href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b04g8hrd">The Lost Genius of Judee Sill</a>, and instantly fell in love with her music and her world. That’s the Spirit is from her third album, Dreams Come True, which was unreleased in her lifetime. It sounds like her freest piece of music as there are so many other musicians playing on it, whereas on her previous albums she generally did everything.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/08/thomas-cohen-playlist-laura-nyro-kate-anna-mcgarrigle-alain-goraguer">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Stone Roses to release new single on Thursday night</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/stone-roses-to-release-new-single-on-wednesday-night</link>
      <description><p>The track will be the Manchester band’s first new music in 21 years</p><p>The Stones Roses have announced that a new single will be released at 8pm on Thursday night. They have given no clues as to the title, only the tersest of announcements: “The Stone Roses will release a new single tonight at 8pm.”</p><p>The new song will be their first new studio material since the B-sides to the single Ten Storey Love Song in March 1995 – fans have been waiting 21 years since the band revealed Moses and Ride On, neither of which featured on the album Second Coming.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/stone-roses-to-release-new-single-on-wednesday-night">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Yacht apologise for 'not getting it' over their sex tape PR stunt</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/yacht-apologise-fake-tape-pr-stunt</link>
      <description><p>LA band say they made an ‘egregious mistake’ in pretending to have had a sex tape stolen and leaked, in order to promote their new single</p><p>After being widely criticised, the Los Angeles band Yacht have apologised for the “egregious mistake” of claiming to have had a sex tape leaked to the internet.</p><p>On Monday, Yacht’s Jona Bechtolt and Claire Evans – who are in a relationship – posted on Facebook claiming a film they had made for private use had been leaked by a “morally abject person”, against whom they were taking legal action. “We hope you understand that this is not a delicious scandal. This is an exploitation,” they wrote. Shortly afterwards, they announced that to gain control of the situation, they would sell the sex tape themselves. They were besieged with messages of support from fans outraged on their behalf.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/yacht-apologise-fake-tape-pr-stunt">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Desert Trip festival reportedly sells out in less than three hours</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/desert-trip-festival-sells-out-rolling-stones-paul-mccartney-roger-waters-bob-dylan-the-who-neil-young</link>
      <description><p>The boomer-friendly event, headlined by the Rolling Stones, Paul McCartney and Roger Waters, predicted to be the highest-grossing event in music history</p><p>The Desert Trip festival – featuring the Rolling Stones, Bob Dylan, Paul McCartney, Neil Young, Roger Waters and the Who – sold out all its 70,000 three-day tickets for each of the festival’s two weekends in under three hours, <a draggable="true" href="http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/7364705/desert-trip-concert-mccartney-rolling-stones-sold-out">Billboard reports</a>.</p><p>Although the festival’s organisers – Goldenvoice and AEG z – have not made an official announcement about how quickly all tickets for the event have sold, Billboard reports that its sources say both Desert Trip weekends – 9-11 October and 16-18 October – sold out in less than three hours. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/desert-trip-festival-sells-out-rolling-stones-paul-mccartney-roger-waters-bob-dylan-the-who-neil-young">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Man who prescribed Prince drugs before death is obstetrics specialist</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/prince-death-prescription-drug-doctor-family-practitioner-obstetrics</link>
      <description><p>Why the singer sought out family doctor Michael Todd Schulenberg remains unclear, as police examine Prince’s computer hard drives for evidence of online prescriptions</p><p>If Prince was seeking help for a problem with prescription drugs, it would make sense for him to turn to a Californian addiction specialist known for new ideas on treatment. Less clear is why he sought care from a local family care physician, specialising in obstetrics, who met with Prince twice in the weeks before his death and prescribed him unknown medications. </p><p>The day Prince died, he was scheduled to meet with the son of Dr Howard Kornfeld, the California specialist in addiction treatment and pain management. But in the weeks before Prince’s death on 21 April, he twice met Dr Michael Todd Schulenberg, who worked at a Minnetonka clinic a few miles from Prince’s Paisley Park studio and home, according to search warrant documents released Tuesday. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/prince-death-prescription-drug-doctor-family-practitioner-obstetrics">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Hip-hop star triggers Twitter storm after posting racist and homophobic comments aimed at former One Direction singer</p><p>Azealia Banks has been dropped from her headlining slot at a British musical festival after posting racist and homophobic tweets towards former One Direction member Zayn Malik.</p><p>The American musician began trending worldwide after she posted the string of comments which referred to Malik in highly derogatory terms.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/11/azealia-banks-axed-uk-music-festival-zayn-malik-twitter">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Riccardo Muti to return to La Scala for first time since 2005</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/11/riccardo-muti-return-la-scala-milan</link>
      <description><p>Maestro who quit as Milan opera house’s musical director amid acrimony will conduct two concerts in January</p><p>Riccardo Muti, the celebrated Italian musical conductor, will make a dramatic return to opera’s spiritual home La Scala in Milan, in what appears to be a burying of the hatchet between the Italian maestro and the opera house after a falling out in 2005.</p><p>La Scala said Muti, who serves as a musical director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, would perform two concerts in Milan in January as part of the Chicago group’s European tour.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/11/riccardo-muti-return-la-scala-milan">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Gene Simmons apologises after calling Prince's death 'pathetic'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/11/gene-simmons-apologises-prince-death-pathetic-kiss-newsweek</link>
      <description><p>‘I have a long history of getting angry at what drugs do,’ explains Kiss singer as he backtracks on comments made in Newsweek interview</p><p>The surprise wasn’t so much that Kiss’s Gene Simmons might say something provocative and inflammatory about the death of Prince, but that he might then backtrack and apologise. After <a href="http://www.newsweek.com/gene-simmons-reflects-bowie-prince-deaths-457851?rx=us">telling Newsweek</a> it was “pathetic that he killed himself”, Simmons <a href="https://twitter.com/genesimmons/status/730199305793871874">issued a public mea culpa on Twitter</a>, admitting he “just got such shit from my family for my big mouth again. I apologise.”</p><p>Simmons had told Newsweek that Prince’s death, was “a choice”, adding: “His drugs killed him. What do you think, he died from a cold?” He had also said: “Prince was heads, hands and feet above all the rest of them. I thought he left Michael [Jackson] in the dust.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/11/gene-simmons-apologises-prince-death-pathetic-kiss-newsweek">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>David Bowie's second album breaks Discogs' price record</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/11/david-bowie-second-album-breaks-discogs-price-record-space-oddity</link>
      <description><p>Vinyl copy of the album that was later retitled Space Oddity has sold for nearly £5,000 in the wake of the singer’s death</p><p>An original copy of David Bowie’s second album has become the most expensive record ever sold on the record collectors’ site Discogs.</p><p>The original UK pressing of the 1969 album David Bowie – which was later retitled Space Oddity – fetched $6,826 (£4,722), beating the record set in 2015 by Chung King Can Suck It, a limited-edition 12in by the New York band Judge, a copy of which sold for $6,048 (£4,183).</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/11/david-bowie-second-album-breaks-discogs-price-record-space-oddity">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>AC/DC review – Axl Rose brings menace as rock legends pull off a triumph</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/08/acdc-review-axl-rose-lisbon-first-gig</link>
      <description><p>The Guns N’ Roses singer might have been confined to a ‘throne’, but he delivered a masterly first appearance fronting AC/DC</p><p>AC/DC couldn’t really have handled the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/06/axl-rose-brian-johnson-acdc-do-justice">departure of their singer Brian Johnson</a> much worse – a curt statement on their website announcing he could no longer tour, owing to hearing loss, and their intention to continue with a stand-in – short of announcing a compulsory redundancy programme for all Florida-resident geordies with a penchant for caps. Their fanbase, normally unquestioningly loyal, reacted with unexpected irritation: refunds for upcoming shows were demanded (and given), and many – <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2016/mar/10/ac-dc-brian-johnson-hearing-tour-dates-fans-acdc-call-quits">me included</a> – questioned whether the band should continue at all.<br></p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/06/axl-rose-brian-johnson-acdc-do-justice">Axl Rose determined to 'do justice' to Brian Johnson with AC/DC shows</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/08/acdc-review-axl-rose-lisbon-first-gig">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p><strong>Middle Temple Hall, London</strong><br>The Cardiff Singer of the World moved fluently between Liszt, Berg, Tchaikovsky and Rachmaninov in a confident London recital debut</p><p>Last June <a href="http://www.tact4art.com/en/artist/Nadine-Koutcher-4-17.html">Nadine Koutcher</a> took the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/jun/22/bbc-cardiff-singer-of-the-world-nadine-koutcher-belarus-soprano">2015 Cardiff Singer of the World</a> title by storm. Now, nearly a year on, the <a href="https://www.templemusic.org/">Temple Music Foundation</a> pulled off the notable coup of presenting her London recital debut in Middle Temple Hall, with its artistic director <a href="http://juliusdrake.com/">Julius Drake</a> as her considerable accompanist.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/jun/22/bbc-cardiff-singer-of-the-world-nadine-koutcher-belarus-soprano">BBC Cardiff Singer of the World review – exceptional technique and instinctive musicality shine through in a strong final</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/nadine-koutcher-middle-temple-hall-london-review">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Adelson e Salvini - a curious and uneven Bellini rarity, beautifully performed</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/adelson-e-salvini-barbican-london-review-bbcso-opera-rara</link>
      <description><p><strong>Barbican, London</strong><br>Opera Rara’s excellent singers complemented outstanding playing from the BBC Symphony Orchestra under Daniele Rustioni</p><p><a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/education/2001/nov/02/arts.highereducation">Bellini</a>’s Adelson e Salvini dates from 1825. It was his first opera, written for a student cast at the Naples Conservatory, where Bellini himself, aged only 24, was a star pupil in his final year in composition class. It was popular during its opening run and got him noticed, but it was soon eclipsed by the works that launched his international career and was never revived in his lifetime. <a href="http://www.opera-rara.com/">Opera Rara</a><a draggable="true" href="http://www.opera-rara.com/%5D's">’s</a> concert performance, conducted by <a draggable="true" href="http://www.artistsmanagement.com/amc-artists/daniele-rustioni/">Daniele Rustioni</a> and semi-staged by Kenneth Richardson, was one of its still infrequent modern outings.</p><p>It’s a curious piece, at times atypical, yet prophetic of much that followed. A bittersweet comedy, it’s set in 18th<sup>-</sup>century Ireland, where the Anglo-Irish Lord Adelson is having trouble with Salvini, a somewhat unstable Italian painter in his employment, who has fallen inconveniently and unrequitedly in love with Adelson’s fiancee Nelly. The proposed marriage is also under threat elsewhere. Back in London, Adelson’s father – he never appears on stage – considers the match socially disadvantageous. In Ireland, meanwhile, for reasons that are never adequately explained, Nelly’s odious uncle Colonel Struley is plotting with his sidekick Geronio to have his niece kidnapped.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/adelson-e-salvini-barbican-london-review-bbcso-opera-rara">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Father John Misty review – Jim Morrison’s head on Jarvis Cocker’s body</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/father-john-misty-review-academy-leeds</link>
      <description><p><strong>Academy, Leeds<br></strong>The crazed Casanova doesn’t so much own the stage as lease the land for miles around in a pelvis-thrusting, guitar-hurling show</p><p>Father John Misty has just begun his fourth song when there’s a commotion in the crowd. “Do we have a medical emergency?” he asks, as the music stops and house lights come up. Eventually, normality resumes, and his band simply pick up <a draggable="true" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SV8f1pexhc4">Only Son of the Ladiesman</a> where they left off – where the song’s lothario protagonist has died, and his “used body” is being flailed at his funeral by numerous irate conquests. “I wouldn’t want a medical emergency in that song,” quips the Father, drily.</p><p>Everything seems to be turning out right for Josh Hillman. In his 20s, as J Tillman, he released several earnest singer-songwriter albums that were mostly ignored. He drummed in Fleet Foxes, before a psychedelic experience provided the revelation that led to the Father John Misty persona: a tongue-in-cheek, wry, drug-crazed Casanova. We first heard him on 2012’s <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2012/dec/20/father-john-misty-fear-fun-review">Fear Fun</a>, but last year’s superior follow-up, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/feb/05/father-john-misty-i-love-you-honeybear-review">I Love You, Honeybear</a>, turned him into an international star. This time – inspired by hismarriage to film-maker Emma Garr - the songs used the new persona to explore love and, ironically, leave him more emotionally exposed than he was before. When he drops to one knee to sing, <a draggable="true" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eg4xkW2Zt5A">“I can hardly believe I’ve found you and I’m terrified by that”</a>, it’s part theatre, part raw honesty of a kind songwriters generally shy away from.<br tabindex="-1"></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/father-john-misty-review-academy-leeds">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The Magic Flute review – Fischer conducts with infectious joy</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/11/the-magic-flute-review-royal-festival-hall-ivan-fischer</link>
      <description><p><strong>Royal Festival Hall, London<br></strong>The Budapest Festival Orchestra’s staged concert, directed by conductor Iván Fischer, was a real treat</p><p>Always one to do things differently, conductor <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2008/sep/19/classicalmusicandopera.tomservice">Iván Fischer</a> has taken up opera direction of late. For his current European tour with the <a draggable="true" href="http://www.bfz.hu/en/">Budapest Festival Orchestra</a>, he is presenting a staged concert – in effect a multimedia version – of The Magic Flute. Fischer reminds us that Mozart’s opera is, despite the gloss with which it is often saddled, essentially a fairytale. On a huge video screen behind the orchestra, we see the turning pages of an illustrated storybook, from which the characters emerge.</p><p>The opera is sung in German, although six actors deliver the dialogue in English. Fischer’s direction is witty, playful and non-interventionist, and there are some fine insights. Having a young, handsome Sarastro (<a draggable="true" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p72NPAzyX-Q">Krisztián Cser</a>) tellingly makes him a rival to <a draggable="true" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OVq0_fZ0pw4">Bernard Richter</a>’s Tamino for the affections of <a draggable="true" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i8YHZjxEFJQ">Hanna-Elisabeth Müller</a>’s Pamina. Only Rodolphe Briand’s Monostatos, in bondage gear, strikes a slightly awkward note.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/11/the-magic-flute-review-royal-festival-hall-ivan-fischer">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Shez Raja review – inventive bassist gives jazz fusion a good name</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/11/shez-raja-review-jazz</link>
      <description><p><strong>Pizza Express Jazz Club, London<br></strong>Raja turned Indo-jazz on its head with everything from funky bass to freestyle rap</p><p>When the term <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/news/2004/mar/13/guardianobituaries.artsobituaries1">Indo-jazz fusions</a> first turned up in the 1960s, it often represented cool-bop saxes picking their way through intricate mazes of western melody and Indian ragas. <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2010/jul/08/shez-raja-collective-cd-review">Shez Raja</a> takes a more robust approach, with his fat Fender-bass sound and guitar-hero strutting, Indian melodies chattering against pounding funk, synths, electric violins and freestyle rap. Raja’s third album, Gurutopia, has trumpet star Randy Brecker and former Miles guitarist Mike Stern in its lineup, but the charismatic saxophonist and rapper Soweto Kinch and versatile guitarist John Etheridge occupied their guest spots at the London launch.</p><p>“Back to the Punjab via Soho!” Raja declared, as Pascal Roggen’s spacey electric violin shimmered and singer Monika Lidke’s vocal line took off into high-register swerves. Kinch launched into an improvised rap, following it with an unfettered alto-sax break. On Chakras on the Wall, Kinch and fellow saxist Vasilis Xenopoulos swapped heated licks, while Mystic Radikal used devious descents to coax a shapely and long-limbed improv from Kinch. Rock’n’Rollup began with a catchy sax and violin hook, then Etheridge delivered a blast of choppy chord-work and Hendrix-like wails, before Raja came in with a surprisingly contemplative bass-guitar solo. Shez Raja proved here that he runs a tailor-made festival band with a unique identity.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/11/shez-raja-review-jazz">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/jazz">Jazz</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/music">Music</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/culture">Culture</category>
      <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 14:15:41 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/11/shez-raja-review-jazz</guid>

    <item>
      <title>Elvis Costello review – stripped-back star at his impish best</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/11/elvis-costello-review-palladium-london</link>
      <description><p><strong>Palladium, London</strong><br>Costello is on playful form in a show that pays tribute to 60s light entertainment</p><p>“Welcome to my opening night at the London Palladium – I’ve been waiting to say that since I was seven years old,” smirks <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/elviscostello">Elvis Costello</a> on the first of his solo Detour tour’s four nights in the illustrious home of light entertainment. He’s certainly set out to make that seven-year-old’s Tarby-hosted dreams a reality. Dominated by “on air” signs and a 20ft 60s television set screening test-card photos from Costello’s Liverpool childhood, when he was known as Declan MacManus, the stage set reflects the experience of watching Sunday Night at the London Palladium in 1962 – Synecdoche, Bruce Forsyth, if you will – and from it Costello delivers the most revealing show of his career.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2016/jan/27/elvis-costello-10-of-the-best">Elvis Costello: 10 of the best</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/11/elvis-costello-review-palladium-london">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>LSO/Andsnes/Flor review – nuanced and alive</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/10/lso-andsnes-flor-review-barbican-london</link>
      <description><p><strong>Barbican, London<br></strong>The indisposition of Daniel Harding meant that Leif Ove Andsnes directed Mozart’s Piano Concerto No 20 from the keyboard in a classy performance</p><p>Sometimes, if you want a job doing you have to do it yourself. This was the first of the Artist Portrait concerts the LSO is putting on in London for pianist <a href="http://www.andsnes.com/">Leif Ove Andsnes</a>, a repeat of the event that had opened the Brighton festival the day before. Both were to have been conducted by Daniel Harding but, with Harding ill, it fell to Andsnes himself to direct Mozart’s Piano Concerto No 20.</p><p>Seated at the keyboard with his back to us, with the piano lid entirely removed so that there was nothing to bounce his sound towards the audience, Andsnes wasn’t always ideally balanced with the orchestra; at times one wanted a leaner, more transparent string sound. Yet Andsnes’s cool but shapely piano lines were never entirely masked. The finale got off to a nicely fiery start, and Andsnes resisted the temptation to make us jump at the <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mDUb7s3BME0">theme’s jarring, pointy chord</a> every time it came around. This was typically classy stuff from Andsnes – playing that didn’t draw undue attention to itself, and yet was far too nuanced and alive to be described as understated.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/10/lso-andsnes-flor-review-barbican-london">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Kronos Quartet review – sonic Slinkys and exploding bombs</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/10/kronos-quartet-review-barbican-london</link>
      <description><p><strong>Barbican, London<br></strong>The virtuoso ensemble performed no less than six UK premieres, with Mary Kouyoumdjian’s Bombs of Beirut providing an explosive finale</p><p>Entirely new in <a href="http://kronosquartet.org/">Kronos</a>’s Barbican programme was Seiche by Martin Green (<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/may/29/lau-interview-folk-music-lau-land-the-bell-that-never-rang">of folk group Lau</a>), whose title refers to a form of wave and which made memorable use of two of Green’s newly invented Kronoscillators – stretched out and amplified Slinkys whose sonic impact proved every bit as extraordinary as the sight of them being played by violinist David Harrington and cellist Sunny Yang.</p><p>No less than six UK premieres featured, three of them written for the virtuoso ensemble’s Fifty for the Future project, which will see as many composers creating pieces for student or emerging professional quartets.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/10/kronos-quartet-review-barbican-london">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Yung Lean review – Sad Boys say it with a fistful of flowers</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/10/yung-lean-review-sad-boys</link>
      <description><p><strong>Art School, Glasgow<br></strong>The Swedish rapper and his crew keep their teenage fans jumping for joy with a twisted, trippy production and a showering of red roses</p><p>Swedish rapper Jonatan Aron Leandoer Håstad AKA Yung Lean has notched up millions of streams, <a href="http://www.aftonbladet.se/nojesbladet/musik/rockbjornen/article19256482.ab">Justin Bieber practically wants to be him</a> and tonight, as he concludes a world tour, he has an audience of teenage and early twentysomething peers eating out of his palm. Happy days for the most melancholy man in hip-hop.</p><p>The 19-year-old Stockholmer’s appeal remains too niche to be hailed a youth culture phenomenon, but it has the trappings of one. With his dark, doleful, semi-ironic raps about drugs, sex, designer sportswear, Nintendo, Arizona Iced Tea and more drugs, often accompanied with bizarre self-made borderline self-parody <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=stgrSjynPKs">viral sensation videos</a>, Lean and his Sad Boys crew (DJ/producer Yung Sherman and MC Bladee flank their leader tonight) have become cultural influencers for a swath of internet-parented post-millennials.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/10/yung-lean-review-sad-boys">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/09/kel-assouf-review-rich-mix-london</link>
      <description><p><strong>Rich Mix, London<br></strong>Tuareg influences fuse with heavy rock guitars and keyboard solos in full-tilt songs about love, hypocrisy and exile</p><p>If <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/nov/22/tinariwen-live-in-paris-album-review-oukis-nasuf-n-asuf-wedge-records-lalla-badi-tinde-azawad">Tinariwen</a> and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/oct/21/tamikrest-review">Tamikrest</a> are the masters of Tuareg desert blues-rock, then Kel Assouf show how the music of the Sahara sounds once it has migrated to Europe and fused with other influences. It’s a style that reflects the history of the band’s singer, songwriter and guitarist Anana Harouna.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/09/kel-assouf-review-rich-mix-london">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Radiohead: A Moon Shaped Pool review – something they've never achieved before</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/global/2016/may/08/radiohead-a-moon-shaped-pool-review</link>
      <description><p>Radiohead have always sounded like a band in constant motion: every album has seemed like an agitated shift from the last<br>(XL)</p><p>Last Tuesday, the world was treated to the improbable spectacle of tastemaking US music website Pitchfork <a href="http://pitchfork.com/thepitch/1133-decoding-the-politics-in-radioheads-burn-the-witch-video/">earnestly trying to explain</a> 1960s and 70s UK kids’ show Trumpton to its American readers. Their London-based contributing editor was drafted in, the better to elucidate the importance of Pugh, Pugh and Barney McGrew, as was the son-in-law of the show’s 96-year-old creator, whose solitary quote – “I’m not aware of anything” – winningly suggested a man quite keen to get the bloke from Pitchfork off the phone. </p><p>Elsewhere, parallels were drawn between Trumpton and what might become of America were Donald Trump to become president, which feels like rather a harsh judgment on the seemingly benign regime of the mayor and Mr Troop the town clerk.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/global/2016/may/08/radiohead-a-moon-shaped-pool-review">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Anohni: Hopelessness review – a radical album for a time of crisis</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/08/anohni-hopelessness-review-antony-and-johnsons</link>
      <description><p>(Rough Trade)</p><p>This extraordinary album, authored by the artist formerly known as <a href="http://www.antonyandthejohnsons.com/">Antony and the Johnsons,</a> is all about radical changes, and radical change.</p><p>Having excised the letter T, Antony is now Anohni, bringing both brand and public face in line with Anohni’s long-held female identification among intimates. Gone are the Johnsons, the non-ensemble who used to underscore Antony’s emotive vibrato. Two digital producers at the vanguard of electronica replace them – <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/mar/14/hudson-mohawke-kanye-west-producer">Hudson Mohawke</a> and <a href="http://pitchfork.com/artists/28187-oneohtrix-point-never/">Oneohtrix Point Never</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/08/anohni-hopelessness-review-antony-and-johnsons">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Hatebreed: The Concrete Confessional review – vital, ferocious heavy music</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/hatebreed-the-concrete-confessional-review-jamey-jasta-heavy-music</link>
      <description><p>(Nuclear Blast)</p><p>Having walked a straight and narrow musical path for 22 years, <a href="http://www.hatebreed.com/">Hatebreed</a> might reasonably expect to find that their brutish metallic hardcore formula has succumbed to the law of diminishing returns. There must be, one assumes, only so many ways to bellow motivational slogans and snarling threats over crunching, low-slung riffs before the whole scowling shebang starts to wear thin. But as they have consistently proved over the past two decades, <a href="http://www.jameyjasta.com/">Jamey Jasta</a> and crew are an irresistible, unifying force in heavy music, and they sound more vital and ferocious than ever here. The <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Concrete_Confessional">Concrete Confessional</a> makes occasional detours from the expected myopic forward charge: Looking Down the Barrel of Today is pure, knowing Slayer worship; From the Grace We’ve Fallen features the rare sound of Jasta singing an actual tune; and The Apex Within is slow burning thrash with Misfits trimmings. But the whole point of Hatebreed has always been to pulverise willing participants with simplicity, power and positivity. In that regard, the furiously precise likes of Seven Enemies and Dissonance amount to jolting shots of pure musical adrenaline.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/hatebreed-the-concrete-confessional-review-jamey-jasta-heavy-music">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/popandrock">Pop and rock</category>

    <item>
      <title>Yak: Alas Salvation review – a force of nature</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/yak-alas-salvation-review-pop-cd-octopus-electrical</link>
      <description><p>(Octopus Electrical)</p><p>It can sometimes be hard to feel optimistic about rowdy, new guitar music. So much sounds grubby and calculated, grabbing at the receding coat-tails of past fads. And then you come across a band like <a draggable="true" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lnu_GUpOVh0">Yak</a>, a three-piece whose live shows are a force of nature, and whose debut album is barely less than that. Credit must go to producer Steve Mackey, who captures the sense of a band whose instruments sound almost as if they’re playing themselves. Everything’s in the red, the guitars sound as if they wondered what it would sound like if you layered 60s garage rock, <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2015/oct/14/the-stooges-10-of-the-best">Stooges</a>-style noise, 70s punk and a couple of pneumatic drills on top of each other: it’s like being run over by a steamroller for 41 minutes, but in a good way. You’re unlikely to be writing critical analyses of the lyrics, but you don’t need to with a record that sounds as exciting as this. Even better, there’s melody to go with noise. What with the new album from <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/08/white-lung-paradise-album-review">White Lung</a>, too, there’s hope for the rowdies yet. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/yak-alas-salvation-review-pop-cd-octopus-electrical">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Oscar: Cut and Paste review – fay Britpop with glorious melodies</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/oscar-cut-and-paste-pop-cd-review-britpop-scheller-wichita</link>
      <description><p>(Wichita)</p><p><a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/apr/23/new-band-of-day-oscar">Oscar Scheller</a> is armed with heart-throb looks and sugary hooks. If it wasn’t for Oscar Pistorius and the Academy Awards rendering his name ungoogleable, not to mention the difficulty of staying afloat as an independent act in 2016, the London crooner’s career would seem preordained. His debut album belligerently establishes this art school boho’s fey <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2014/apr/24/britpop-cultural-abomination-music-blur-oasis">Britpop</a> status: he pummels his songs with dandyish imagery, an adversity to laddishness (“Tell me who I should support / Red team, green team?”) and a tendency for lovestruck melodrama (“Then I see your face and I want to die”). Its songs are bereft of Britpop’s social commentary, and instead its story lies within its DIY creation – a bedroom pop star occupying his days with <a draggable="true" href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2015/oct/17/ten-of-the-best-music-making-apps-for-beginners">GarageBand</a> rather than narcotics. Cut and Paste’s melodies are glorious – single Daffodil Days is surging and swoonsome – but with lyrics so surface, you sometimes wish he’d get out a bit more.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/oscar-cut-and-paste-pop-cd-review-britpop-scheller-wichita">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Joe Driscoll and Sekou Kouyate: Monistic Theory review – fusion with crossover potential</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/joe-driscoll-and-sekou-kouyate-monistic-theory-review-kora</link>
      <description><p>(Cumbancha) </p><p>Six years ago, the American guitarist, rapper and singer-songwriter <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/oct/15/joe-driscoll-sekou-kouyate-review-jazz-cafe-london">Joe Driscoll first teamed up with Sekou Kouyate</a>, one of the finest kora players in west Africa, at a music festival in France. They are still together, after playing hundreds of shows around the world, and creating a confident, engaging fusion of their very different styles. Their <a href="http://store.cumbancha.com/album/monistic-theory">second album</a> is a classy, easygoing affair, with Kouyate’s exquisite kora work and fine, soulful vocals in the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Susu_language">Susu language</a> matched against an often laidback, funky backing and melodic English folk-pop balladry and rap from Driscoll. Songs such as Just Live and Rising Tide are potential <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/jan/26/the-playlist-african-pop-wizkid-eddy-kenzo-mista-silva-and-more">African-pop</a> crossover hits, helped by bass, drums and percussion, with lyrics stressing Driscoll’s cheerfully inclusive philosophy that “we’re all one tribe”. They end with a reminder of why Kouyate has been called <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O37H6NODLDM">“the Hendrix of the kora”</a>, with a furious live reworking of Stevie Wonder’s Master Blaster. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/joe-driscoll-and-sekou-kouyate-monistic-theory-review-kora">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Eagulls: Ullages review – a headlong plunge into 80s angst-rock</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/eagulls-ullages-review-pop-cd-george-mitchell-angst-rock</link>
      <description><p>(Partisan Records)</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2014/feb/27/eagulls-eagulls-review">Eagulls: Eagulls review – exciting times for British guitar music</a> </p><p>The sound of Ullages (an anagram of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2014/feb/27/eagulls-eagulls-review">Eagulls</a>’ name) is bigger and more expansive than the Leeds five-piece’s 2014 debut, but there are fewer catchy tunes. It lacks the urgency, or those moments on the edge of hysteria that were honed from playing the songs live. Instead, Eagulls have plunged headlong into the 80s angst-rock of the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2015/nov/11/the-cure-10-of-the-best">Cure</a> and the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/culture/2001/aug/03/artsfeatures5">Chameleons</a>. Guitars are drenched in reverb, basslines are played in eighth-notes and keys are mostly minor, while singer George Mitchell has perfected his Robert Smith whine.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/eagulls-ullages-review-pop-cd-george-mitchell-angst-rock">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/10/yacht-sex-tape-backlash-undermines-revenge-porn-victims</link>
      <description><p>The LA band is facing backlash over its fake sex tape stunt, which activists say may make it harder for real victims of non-consensual porn to be believed</p><p>Experts on sexual assault have criticised LA band Yacht for creating a fake sex tape to promote their new album, something activists say may make it harder for “revenge porn” victims to be believed.</p><p>Bandmates Jona Bechtolt and Claire Evans, who are in a relationship, announced on Monday on <a href="https://www.facebook.com/yacht/posts/10153803801972479">the group’s Facebook page</a> that a sex tape had been released online “without our previous knowledge nor consent”.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/10/yacht-sex-tape-backlash-undermines-revenge-porn-victims">Continue reading...</a></description>
