    <item>
      <title>Other Music's closure after two decades is a tragedy for New York's crate-diggers</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/10/other-music-new-york-city-record-store-closure</link>
      <description><p>It’s no surprise to see another small business fall prey to gentrification, but the loss of this record store and its knowledgable staff is a particularly bitter blow</p><p>“When <a href="http://www.othermusic.com/">Other Music</a> closes, I’m going to move to LA.” That’s the refrain my friends would hear me say from time to time when talk of whether I would finally wise up and move my struggling film-maker butt to a city where there’s actually real work. But it was actually that simple. The New York of my frustrated teenage dreams, where cool shops were a place to hang out for hours, had slowly given way to something else: a city where luxury hotels, condominiums and tricked-out pharmacies were popping up like hives on the body of a person with a seafood allergy who’d eaten some salmon by mistake. The small, hip store where you could actually find things nobody heard about, converse with a knowledgeable staff, and be assured to walk out with something special, was an endangered species. Yesterday, to the chagrin of anyone with taste, it went extinct. <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/10/arts/music/other-music-record-store-closing.html">Other Music announced it will be closing its doors after more than 20 years on 25 June.</a></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/10/other-music-new-york-city-record-store-closure">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Cult heroes: Danny Fields – the 60s and 70s scenester who made punk happen</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2016/may/10/cult-heroes-danny-fields-ramones-stooges-punk</link>
      <description><p>The former Doors publicist and Warhol Factory member who got the Stooges a record deal and managed the Ramones was there during the most epochal moments of rock history. You can blame him for the Bay City Rollers, too</p><p>A mixed blessing of social media is that it allows pop stars to convey their thoughts directly to fans. While it can be painful to read the unpunctuated trumpetings of some YouTube embryo, it represents a much better deal for fans than was the case in the 1970s, when teen magazines were the immoveable gatekeepers to the stars. American pop fans had an especially hard lot: the biggest magazine, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/16_(magazine)">16</a>, had a distinctly autocratic flavour, with an editor who encouraged readers to address her as <a href="http://www.gloriastavers.com/">Miss Stavers</a> – no first names tolerated – and reputedly flew into a fury when teenage readers turned up at her office. </p><p>Miss Stavers left in 1975 and was replaced by her assistant, Danny Fields, who co-edited 16 (with Randi Reisfeld) for the next five years. In a small but significant way, that changed my life. As a kid who’d discovered 16 towards the end of Stavers’s reign, I was the target audience for Fields’ big strategy, which was to introduce America to the Bay City Rollers. He had a hunch that the Edinburgh group would be the first UK boyband to break the US since the 60s, and featured them on 13 successive covers. It was one of many Fields hunches that proved right: thanks to him, millions of American girls, me included, found their entry-level boyband.<br tabindex="-1"></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2016/may/10/cult-heroes-danny-fields-ramones-stooges-punk">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Led Zeppelin's plagiarism lawsuit: a sign of the times in the music industry</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/09/led-zeppelin-music-plagiarism-lawsuits-samples-chords-lyrics</link>
      <description><p>In an age of declining revenue, suing over chord progressions and samples opens a new revenue stream for disgruntled artists – but such action is nothing new</p><p>It’s hard for musicians to make money these days, given the drain of file-sharing and the lousy wages of streaming. But an increasing number of artists have found another way to generate funds: lawsuits against each other.</p><p>In the past few years, a rash of high-profile legal actions have been launched by stars, or their estates, over copyright infringement. Artists such as <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/15/kendrick-lamar-sued-for-allegedly-copying-bill-withers-song">Kendrick Lamar</a>, Sam Smith and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/mar/10/blurred-lines-pharrell-robin-thicke-copied-marvin-gaye">Robin Thicke</a> have each stood accused of stealing sounds from other musicians in their songs, forcing them either to wage costly court battles or to settle the suits privately for undisclosed sums.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/09/led-zeppelin-music-plagiarism-lawsuits-samples-chords-lyrics">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/music">Music</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/ledzeppelin">Led Zeppelin</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/culture">Culture</category>

    <item>
      <title>Underworld webchat – your questions answered, on the Olympics, Batman and Born Slippy</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/live/2016/may/09/underworld-webchat-barbara-barbara-we-face-a-shining-future</link>
      <description><p>Karl Hyde from Underworld joined us to answer your questions, about everything from how he writes lyrics to the greatness of Glasgow Barrowlands</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-11T13:15:19.451Z">2.15pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>We’ll leave the thanks to the man himself...</p><p>Thank you to everyone who's taken part in this. It's been interesting to talk to you in this way. My thanks to the speedy fingers that have translated my gibberish and I look forward to seeing you all out in the world soon.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-11T13:14:19.471Z">2.14pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p><a href="https://profile.theguardian.com/user/id/14593714">Amaranthus</a> asks:</p><p><em>Now it is so easy to make and produce dance music, do you think the explosion of people making their own stuff (which has flooded the market) is now a negative for people looking for real quality tunes which are lost in a sea of mediocrity?</em></p><p>I think we've always been afloat in the sea of mediocrity, and that has inspired people to react to it. The underground is continually throwing up angry youth who react against the establishment or mediocrity - I would be more worried if the underground wasn't worried and pointing fingers. Then we really would be in trouble. What the ease of access to the recording process has done is to create a generic sound, therefore what I'm seeing now is a groudswell backlash to that, ie modular synthesis, instruments with knobs, strings, reeds, and an exploration in search of idiosyncrasy and personality. And it's working.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/live/2016/may/09/underworld-webchat-barbara-barbara-we-face-a-shining-future">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Radiohead's new album isn't on Spotify. So what? Spotify doesn't need it</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2016/may/09/radiohead-moon-shaped-pool-not-on-spotify-so-what</link>
      <description><p>It’s more dramatic to portray Radiohead and Spotify as being at war, but in truth it’s just business as usual for them both</p><p>A new Radiohead album must mean a new “war” with Spotify. </p><p>As soon as A Moon Shaped Pool was made available on Sunday evening, there was much furrowing of brows, chewing of pencils and alighting on the same point – that it wasn’t available on Spotify. Apart from the first two singles. So, in fact, 18% of the album is on Spotify. But ignore that: the whole album isn’t on Spotify and, as with everything Radiohead do, this immediately took on colossal import. <br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2016/may/09/radiohead-moon-shaped-pool-not-on-spotify-so-what">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>From Steve Reich to rock: why 1976 was a big year for minimal music</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/07/from-steve-reich-to-rock-1976-minimal-music</link>
      <description><p>It was the year of the Sex Pistols, Stevie Wonder and perfect Swedish pop, but 1976 was also the annus mirabilis of minimalism </p><p>If you can remember 1976, you will remember the summer: the hottest and driest in the UK since records began, with standpipes in the streets all over the country. In the news there was the death of Mao and the end of the Cultural Revolution, the American Revolution Bicentennial, the Soweto uprising and the shock resignation of prime minister <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/harold-wilson">Harold Wilson</a>. Less publicised, but ultimately just as significant, events that year included the setting up of <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/apple">Apple</a> Computer Inc and the first reported case of a haemorrhagic fever virus found near a river called the Ebola in Zaire.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/tomserviceblog/2012/oct/22/steve-reich-contemporary-music-guide">A guide to Steve Reich's music</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/07/from-steve-reich-to-rock-1976-minimal-music">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>10 things we learned from Skepta's Konnichiwa</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/06/10-things-we-learned-from-skeptas-konnichiwa</link>
      <description><p>Resistant to American trends and artists who think they can outshine him, Skepta’s release is a one-man show that proves the great grime album is possible</p><p>The last couple of years have seen Canadian megastar Drake declaring his love for grime, from Instagramming stills of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/oct/30/top-boy-reviewed-by-hackney-residents-panel">Top Boy</a> accompanied by slightly cack-handed renditions of UK slang (“real bod man”) to sneaking off from the Brits to appear on stage with fast-rising rap/grime outfit Section Boyz. When the rapper signed to Skepta’s label Boy Better Know, fans relished seeing the two artists working together; as it turns out neither has appeared on the other’s latest release. There was a disgruntled backlash from grime fans when Skepta wasn’t given so much as a verse on <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/29/views-drake-new-album-talking-points">Drake’s recent album, Views</a>, but now Skepta’s returned the favour by keeping Konnichiwa Drizzy free, at no great loss. In fact, “Drake signing to Boy Better Know” is looking increasingly like a piece of pub quiz trivia in grime history. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/06/10-things-we-learned-from-skeptas-konnichiwa">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Walking on sunshine: The Ladies of Too Slow to Disco compilation</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/05/golden-girls-the-ladies-of-too-slow-to-disco-compilation</link>
      <description><p>From singer-songwriter ballads to lavish soul, The Ladies of Too Slow to Disco compilation captures the creativity and optimism of female musicians in 70s California. Here some of them talk about those heady days</p><p>We’ve been primed by so many films and TV series to expect something darker beneath images of 1970s California sunshine and optimism: to believe the smiles are rictus grins, concealing an underbelly of excess, amorality and tragedy. Sometimes, though, it was just fun. “The money was flying,” says Franne (formerly Frannie) Golde, one of the stars of the new compilation <a href="http://tooslowtodisco.com/">The Ladies of Too Slow to Disco</a>. “Limousines from the airport – not just for the artist but for the songwriters, for anyone that you might want in the studio with you to feel relaxed and comfortable – beautiful hotel rooms for everyone, lots of time to do your thing in the studio. It was a great time.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/05/golden-girls-the-ladies-of-too-slow-to-disco-compilation">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Comeback kids: the Jayhawks ride again</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/05/jayhawks-return-paging-mr-proust-new-album</link>
      <description><p>Combining melancholia with sunshine choruses, alt-country pioneers return to their best. ‘Life is dark, but with a beautiful melody,’ says founder Gary Louris </p><p>Perseverance is a virtue many bands run out of after they reach a modicum of success. Divorces, money squabbles, drug problems, boredom – these are the usual culprits cutting bands short before their time.</p><p>So it is a great accomplishment that <a href="http://www.jayhawksofficial.com/">the Jayhawks</a>, a band at the forefront of the alt-country movement of the 1990s, are back with a new album that also happens to be one of their best. No one is as surprised as songwriter-singer Gary Louris that Paging Mr Proust, released last week, has been <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/28/the-jayhawks-paging-mr-proust-review-an-easy-musical-chemistry">received so well by critics</a> and is the basis for one of the most aggressive touring schedules in North America and Europe this year and likely the next: “Appreciative is the word,” he says. “I’m a lot more focused than I used to be.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/05/jayhawks-return-paging-mr-proust-new-album">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/community/2016/may/05/does-david-bowies-blackstar-sleeve-hold-a-secret-help-us-find-out</link>
      <description><p>Owners are claiming to have discovered a secret constellation – but is it an intentional chemical reaction or just a trick of the light?<br></p><p>Record collectors and David Bowie fans – we need you.<br></p><p>After spotting someone claiming <a href="http://imgur.com/DWfh36J">that they left their Blackstar vinyl sleeve in sunlight for a few hours, unintentionally revealing a whole constellation of stars,</a> we wondered whether you would help us test out their discovery (follow the link for instructions).     <item>
      <title>Memes, MP3s and the explosion of album art</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/04/album-artwork-new-evolution-vinyl-mp3-spotify</link>
      <description><p>With the iTunes Store, Spotify and Twitter replacing the record shop, instant recognition and meme-friendliness has spurred an unexpected evolution in cover art</p><p>The first album I properly owned was <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2009/jul/06/michael-jackson-dangerous">Michael Jackson’s Dangerous</a>. Given to me as a present on Christmas Day, 1991, I played the cassette constantly on a chunky Walkman and subjected my family to repeated plays on long car journeys. I was equally obsessed with the artwork; an intricately detailed, multi-layered tableau <a href="https://s-media-cache-ak0.pinimg.com/736x/31/cd/fc/31cdfcdc68d2e948b6650e37cc09f950.jpg">created by artist Mark Ryden over six months</a>. It represented a massive departure from the simpler, more posed artwork of Jackson’s previous albums (1987’s Bad was just him, a snazzy zipped jacket and some red spray paint). The timing for such an aesthetic switch was curious: by the early 90s, music formats had shrunk from the larger canvas of vinyl to cassettes and then to CDs, so trying to spot the artwork’s myriad of hidden treasures – Jackson’s monkey Bubbles, the plasters he wore on his fingers, the minuscule picture of him from the 1984 Grammys – on a tiny cassette cover was like a game of Where’s Wally. </p><p>Its visual complexity was at odds with the way in which fans were consuming music at the time, and is a curious exception in the evolution of the album cover; which tends to mirror the changing formats and consumption methods of the time. Starting with the practicality of the 1940s sleeves – which were used to protect the record – to the punk and prog experimentalism of the 70s through to the bold graphics and controversies of the 80s and 90s and the cleaner lines of the 2000s, artwork offers a broader reflection of the cultural and technological landscape. So what can the images used by artists in 2016 reveal? </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/04/album-artwork-new-evolution-vinyl-mp3-spotify">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Cult heroes – Hank Williams Jr: crusading country boy with a lesson for the left</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2016/may/04/cult-heroes-hank-williams-jr-crusading-country-boy</link>
      <description><p>The Nashville star once compared Obama to Hitler and his rightwing persona can often stray beyond parody, but his musical message is one of inclusion and amity</p><p>In music, rebels and iconoclasts come in many shapes and sizes. And while there may be a perceived correlation between artistic integrity and liberal politics, out in the real world ideology and orientation is of far less importance than direction of travel, and the determination of someone to get to where they’re headed. Just take the case of Randall Williams. </p><p>He was barely old enough to walk when his father, Hiram “Hank” Williams, died in the back seat of a car while being ferried between gigs. Hank Sr hadn’t just been a country star he had minted a string of stereotypes that helped shape our view of the role of the artist in the 20th century. He was among the first musicians to become as famous for the songs he wrote as for the ones he sang written by others, and when those songs spoke of folks looking bleakly across blasted lives and pondering their narrow range of bad options (Hank Sr’s final release before his death was <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=19vApPwWqh8">I’ll Never Get Out of this World Alive</a>) he helped popularise the notion that an artist may be doomed by precognition of their tragic fates, a notion promoted by his self-medicating a spinal problem with drink and drugs. That he’d achieved popularity in spite of, rather than with help from, the country music establishment only seemed to endear him to the people he wrote for and about: men, women and children doing their best to pull themselves up by the bootstraps in an America busy building a new age.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2016/may/04/cult-heroes-hank-williams-jr-crusading-country-boy">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Desert Trip: the festival for the baby boomer with a bucket list</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/03/desert-trip-music-festival-rolling-stones-paul-mccartney-bob-dylan-who</link>
      <description><p>If you greeted the deaths of Bowie and Prince by wishing you’d seen them live while you had the chance, the people behind Coachella have the ideal event for you – at a price</p><p>The <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/03/coachella-boomer-festival-rolling-stones-bob-dylan-tickets">recently announced baby boomer music festival </a>called Desert Trip – set for the beginning of October at the same venue as <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/coachella">Coachella</a>, the Empire Polo Club in Indio, California – has been billed as “once in a lifetime”. That’s a real cute slogan, since most of the acts involved are pushing 80, and I’m not referring to the speed of their cars – they all probably drive rather slowly. If they drive at all. After the untimely deaths of rock icons <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/jan/15/david-bowies-last-days-an-18-month-burst-of-creativity">David Bowie</a> and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/22/prince-obituary">Prince</a>, it stands to reason that we’re going to start losing more beloved musicians. Such is the frailty of human existence.</p><p>Every time someone of that stature dies, it’s a loss felt by fans all around the world. Inevitably, you or one of your friends will say: “Golly, I wish I had just dropped a few hundred dollars to go see [Dead Musician X] when I had the chance.” When the news of Prince’s death broke, I certainly muttered a similar refrain to myself. I’d skipped his monthlong residency at the Forum in Inglewood, California, because at the time I was broke and eating pasta for every meal. It’s easy to take for granted that these people will always be around to entertain you, and sobering when you realize they won’t be.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/03/desert-trip-music-festival-rolling-stones-paul-mccartney-bob-dylan-who">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Beyoncé and beyond: the hottest sounds of summer 2016</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/02/rock-and-pop-summer-arts-preview-2016</link>
      <description><p>Bob, Beyoncé and the Boss top a summer that sees Kendrick Lamar play Hyde Park and Axl Rose front AC/DC. Plus the return of Dexys, ABC – and Adam Ant</p><ul><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/culture/2016/may/02/punk-london-summer-preview-sex-pistols">Pistols reloaded: Alexis Petridis on how to celebrate punk’s 40th birthday</a><br></li></ul><ul><li>Summer culture: <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/02/scorchers-the-hottest-films-of-summer-2016-preview">Film</a> | <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/stage/2016/may/02/the-unmissable-dance-shows-of-summer-2016-preview">Dance</a> | <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/stage/2016/may/02/best-theatre-summer-2016-kenneth-branagh-ralph-fiennes">Theatre</a> | <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/culture/2016/may/03/summer-art-photography-design-architecture-what-to-see">Art</a> | <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/stage/2016/may/04/best-comedy-shows-summer-2016-bridget-christie-sara-pascoe">Comedy</a></li></ul><p>The thrilling revival of Skepta has mirrored that of UK grime itself. Before the Tottenham rapper was owning 2015 with his track Shutdown, his career had become derailed by the lure of major label money, and he was making <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tnar90VEwe4">cheesy tracks about Rolex watches</a> with tacky dance routines in an attempt to mimic Dizzee’s Bonkers rise. Skepta has since found strength through going back to basics, and although comeback album Konnichiwa has been delayed, you get the sense that it’s because he’s determined to get this one right.<br>•6 May, Boy Better Know.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/02/rock-and-pop-summer-arts-preview-2016">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>All surprises: Radiohead and the art of the unconventional album release</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2016/may/02/all-surprises-radiohead-and-art-of-unconventional-album-release</link>
      <description><p>As the rumours of an imminent Radiohead LP grow, we look back at some of the novel ways in which the band have previously put out their music</p><p>Radiohead have become the kings of the unexpected album release. Not only does the album itself often come as a bit of a shock, but the method of its delivery tends to be a surprise. Put it this way: the first person to buy a new Radiohead album isn’t someone at their local Tesco with a crisp new tenner in their hand.</p><p>So how have their releases evolved over the years? Here’s your album-by-album guide to Radiohead – not the music but the way it came out.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2016/may/02/all-surprises-radiohead-and-art-of-unconventional-album-release">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Elvis Costello: ‘Believing you’re being watched is no longer fantasy’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/apr/30/elvis-costello-believing-youre-being-watched-is-no-longer-paranoid-fantasy</link>
      <description><p>The musician, 61, on social media, being British, and his love of curling</p><p><strong>I don’t have any horror stories about the Catholic church. </strong>The nuns who taught me until I was 11 were very kind. I know plenty of people who had traumatic experiences, and I’d disagree with a lot of positions the church takes, but I’m glad that I went to that kind of school. I don’t think I suffered from it. It taught me to read; I can tie my shoelaces.</p><p><strong>Growing up, I heard music a little differently from most people. </strong>If your parents are in music, it’s obviously going to affect you. For one thing, it made the boundaries that people erect between different styles of music invisible. My father [a singer and trumpet player] was obliged to play all sorts: it was his job to learn the songs of the day.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/apr/30/elvis-costello-believing-youre-being-watched-is-no-longer-paranoid-fantasy">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Philip Kives of K-tel – the man who invented the compilation album</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2016/apr/29/philip-kives-k-tel-compilation-album</link>
      <description><p>By applying the principle of pile ’em high, sell ’em cheap to music, Philip Kives revolutionised the industry</p><p>While not as celebrated as someone like Ahmet Ertegun, the urbane force behind Atlantic Records, K-tel founder Philip Kives still had a profound effect on the record business – an industry that he, by his own admission, entered by accident.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/apr/28/philip-kives-ktel-infomercial-dies-87">Philip Kives, K-tel founder and 'wait there's more' infomercial king, dies at 87</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2016/apr/29/philip-kives-k-tel-compilation-album">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/music">Music</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/popandrock">Pop and rock</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/business/musicindustry">Music industry</category>

      <title>YouTube: 'No other platform gives as much money back to creators'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2016/apr/28/youtube-no-other-platform-gives-as-much-money-back-to-creators</link>
      <description><p>In a series of articles on Guardian music this week, artists have demanded more money from YouTube. One of the company’s executives says they have got it wrong – YouTube is actually supporting the music industry </p><p>Lately, there’s been a chorus of music label representatives and artists accusing YouTube of mistreating musicians. As the music industry shifts from a business that mainly sold albums and singles to one that earns money from subscriptions and ads, there are bound to be disagreements.<br></p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/mar/23/youtube-riaa-music-labels-artist-royalties">YouTube and music labels clash again over 'meagre' artist royalties</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2016/apr/28/youtube-no-other-platform-gives-as-much-money-back-to-creators">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Cyndi Lauper: 'In North Carolina I insisted on a transgender bathroom'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/27/cyndi-lauper-interview-country-album-north-carolina-lgbt-laws</link>
      <description><p>Having conquered pop and musical theatre, Lauper went to Nashville to record a country album, Detour. She talked about working with legends and why she chose to perform in a state with anti-LGBT laws</p><p>While Cyndi Lauper will no doubt be remembered for her mid-1980s pop hits (<a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PIb6AZdTr-A">Girls Just Want to Have Fun</a>, <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VdQY7BusJNU">Time After Time</a>), since then she has very successfully turned her hand to musical theater and traditional roots music. </p><p>Besides winning a Tony award for her original score to her Broadway show <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/stage/2013/apr/05/kinky-boots-review-broadway">Kinky Boots</a>, she earned a Grammy nomination for <a href="http://www.allmusic.com/album/memphis-blues-mw0001990213">Memphis Blues</a>, a collection of traditional blues covers. Next week she releases Detour, a collection of country music covers spanning the genre’s earliest days of the 1930s through the 1960s. Three days later she will launch an international tour at the historic <a href="http://ryman.com/">Ryman Auditorium</a> in Nashville.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/27/cyndi-lauper-interview-country-album-north-carolina-lgbt-laws">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Music business 'feminism' is little more than branding. Just ask Kesha</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/26/feminism-music-business-branding-beyonce-kesha</link>
      <description><p>Pop stars from Beyoncé to Miley Cyrus have embraced the word, and that’s great – but behind the scenes, the industry is hostile to women</p><p>The unofficial kickoff of music festival season began at Coachella in Indio, California this month, where emerging and big names coalesce for two scorchingly hot, endlessly sweaty weekends. This year followed the formula of previous ones: there was a much-hyped reunion (Guns N’ Roses), breathless media coverage of young celebs in leather shorts and thousands of people dropping molly and <a href="http://time.com/money/4294043/cost-of-coachella/">fending off dehydration with $12 beers</a>. There was another familiar feature as well: for the ninth year in a row, <a draggable="true" href="http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/la-et-ms-coachella-women-problem-20160415-story.html">there were no female headliners</a>. </p><p>Summer music festivals have always leaned male, from long-running sausage parties like the <a href="http://vanswarpedtour.com/warped-101/">Warped Tour</a> and <a href="http://www.ozzfest.com/">Ozzfest </a>to more ostensibly unisex ones like <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2014/mar/26/lollapalooza-festival-lineup-monotony-outkast-eminem-arctic-monkeys">Lollapalooza</a>. <a href="http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/sarah-mclachlan-says-lilith-fair-is-done-20110311">Lilith Fair</a>, the successful but short-lived lady-focused festival that debuted in the late 1990s, was a direct reaction to the mulishness of concert promoters who feared that having more than a few female acts on a summer bill would drive away their bread-and-butter demographic of young males. Still, a lot has changed in the past couple of decades, and when it comes to women in rock and pop music, one thing in particular has changed in just the past few years: namely, the marketing of “feminist” as a bona fide brand identity. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/26/feminism-music-business-branding-beyonce-kesha">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Beyoncé's Lemonade is about much more than Jay Z and infidelity | Ijeoma Oluo</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/apr/25/beyonce-lemonade-jay-z-infidelity-emotional-project-depths</link>
      <description><p>I was not expecting to be cracked wide open by this project. I was not expecting to shed a lifetime of tears. But I did</p><p>While I have always been a fan of Beyoncé, I’m not someone you’d consider one of the beyhive. So I am rarely the first to hear about Beyoncé’s latest projects. Most of my weekend was dedicated to thinking about Prince, crying about Prince and making my son watch videos of Prince. But when I dried my tears Sunday morning, I saw that Lemonade had dropped the evening before. And according to press, this was an album about Jay Z.</p><p>To read early headlines, Lemonade is about Beyoncé and Jay Z, or it’s about what a dog Jay Z is, it’s about that infamous elevator fight, it’s about Beyoncé being mad at Jay Z, it’s about Beyoncé’s heartbreak over Jay Z. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/apr/25/beyonce-lemonade-jay-z-infidelity-emotional-project-depths">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Radiohead: Burn the Witch review – a return the world might have hoped for</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2016/may/03/radiohead-burn-the-witch-review-the-kind-of-return-the-world-might-have-hoped-for</link>
      <description><p>Radiohead unveiled their new single – and a video that crosses Trumpton and The Wicker Man – on Tuesday afternoon. And it’s brilliant</p><p>And finally the first music arrived. What seems to be the first track from Radiohead’s new album was launched on their website on Tuesday afternoon, accompanied by a video featuring animation in the style of Bob Bura and John Hardwick, the creators of Trumpton, Chigley and Camberwick Green. Burn the Witch had been trailed on Instagram, but the brief clips didn’t give much clue as to what music we might expect. But what arrived was thrilling – a burst of taut, tense music, driven by pizzicato strings, that had more in common with conventional rock than some hints had led us to believe – Brian Message, from their management firm, had claimed the new album will sound “like nothing you’ve ever heard”.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/04/disarmingly-melodic-fans-and-a-newbie-review-radioheads-new-single-burn-the-witch">'Disarmingly melodic': fans (and a newbie) review Radiohead's new single Burn the Witch</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2016/may/03/radiohead-burn-the-witch-review-the-kind-of-return-the-world-might-have-hoped-for">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Spike Lee hosts Brooklyn street party to honor Prince – video</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/video/2016/apr/22/spike-lee-hosts-brooklyn-street-party-to-honour-prince-video</link>
      <description><p>Film-maker Spike Lee drew a crowd of roughly 1,000 people for an impromptu street party in honor of Prince, presiding from the porch of his Brooklyn headquarters in New York in a purple T-shirt, in homage to the Prince song Purple Rain. Tributes have been pouring in from all over the world for the 57-year-old singer <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/21/prince-dead-music-superstar-57">who was found dead</a> at his suburban Minneapolis compound.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/video/2016/apr/22/spike-lee-hosts-brooklyn-street-party-to-honour-prince-video">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Prince performing While My Guitar Gently Weeps at Rock and Roll Hall of Fame induction – video</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/video/2016/apr/22/prince-performing-while-my-guitar-gently-weeps-at-rock-and-roll-hall-of-fame-induction-video</link>
      <description><p>Prince performs While My Guitar Gently Weeps alongside Tom Petty, Steve Winwood, Jeff Lyne and others in 2004. The performance was a two-minute guitar solo with no singing. At one point, he leaned backwards off the front of the stage and a handler had to hold him up. At the end, he took his guitar off and threw it into the air. <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/21/prince-dead-music-superstar-57">Prince died at his home on Thursday</a> at Paisley Park in suburban Minneapolis</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/video/2016/apr/22/prince-performing-while-my-guitar-gently-weeps-at-rock-and-roll-hall-of-fame-induction-video">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/video/2016/apr/21/prince-dies-music-career-video</link>
      <description><p>Prince, a musical superstar and pioneer, who released 39 studio albums and won seven Grammy awards, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/21/prince-dead-music-superstar-57">died on Thursday aged 57</a>. The star had been reported unwell several days before his death, including a visit to a hospital in Illinois last week. He died in his home studio in Chanhassen, Minnesota</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/video/2016/apr/21/prince-dies-music-career-video">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Mick Jagger: 'If you start thinking how pretty the sunset is, you get lost'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/dec/08/mick-jagger-rolling-stones-glastonbury-interview-review-2013</link>
      <description>The Rolling Stones showed their enduring power in a storming Glastonbury debut<br /><br />• <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/series/the-observers-faces-of-2013">See the Observer's faces of 2013 in full here</a><p>"It's the alternative Ascot, let's face it," says the sprightly 70-year-old sitting opposite me, talking about the Glastonbury festival, before adding quickly: "Not that I've ever been to the proper Ascot."</p><p>Sometimes it's hard to remember that Mick Jagger isn't just a playboy of the western world – before all that, he was the singer in a rock'n'roll band and, 50 years on, that much hasn't changed. In fact,&nbsp;try to get him talking about how the Rolling Stones revolutionised society in the 60s, or about the lifestyle he pursues during downtime&nbsp;from the group, and he's not really having it. Instead, he talks about the meticulous&nbsp;preparation that went into playing <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/jun/30/rolling-stones-glastonbury-2013-review" title="">Glastonbury for the first time</a> this summer and the group's two&nbsp;subsequent shows in Hyde Park.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/dec/08/mick-jagger-rolling-stones-glastonbury-interview-review-2013">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Jarvis Cocker: 'I have a terrible temper on me'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/feb/10/jarvis-cocker-i-have-a-terrible-temper-on-me</link>
      <description><p>It’s 20 years since the Pulp singer’s backside upstaged Michael Jackson at the Brit awards. Shortly afterwards, Dave Simpson interviewed him for Melody Maker – <a href="http://www.rocksbackpages.com/">Rock’s Backpages</a> digs out a classic interview</p><p><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/sep/04/why-jarvis-cocker-is-making-waves-proms">Jarvis Cocker</a> is famous. He is, arguably, the fifth most famous man in Britain, behind John Major, Frank Bruno, Will Carling and Michael Barrymore. Suddenly, Jarvis Cocker has become ubiquitous. As I write, <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/the-northerner/2015/dec/11/coronation-street-north-55-years-1985-archive">Coronation Street</a>’s predatorial hairdresser Maxine is eyeing up another victim as Cocker’s Common People plays in the background. In a few hours, jovial buffoon Chris Evans will present the scarily compulsive TFI Friday, while a life-size cardboard cut-out of Cocker gazes, spectre-like, over his shoulder.<br tabindex="-1"></p><p> This morning, the daily papers carried the usual ream of stories about Jarvis. In the Guardian, two pages are devoted to an analysis of Cocker’s success, post the <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/culture/gallery/2012/feb/19/10-best-brit-award-moments">Brits incident</a>, which they calculate has earned him an additional three quarters of a million quid’s worth of free advertising and sold him an extra 50,000 albums, all the result of one single burst of spontaneous behaviour.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/feb/10/jarvis-cocker-i-have-a-terrible-temper-on-me">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Buddy Holly: the rocker next door – a classic profile by Mick Farren</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/feb/03/buddy-holly-rocker-next-door-classic-profile-nme-1975</link>
      <description><p>On the 57th anniversary of the his tragic death we revisit this profile of the clean-cut icon, first published in NME in September 1975 and taken from <a href="http://www.rocksbackpages.com/">Rock’s Backpages</a></p><p>In a frame of reference where you might think of Elvis Presley as an idol and Little Richard as a hero, Buddy Holly has to be considered as an influence.</p><p>Buddy Holly, the first rocker to actually go on stage wearing horn-rimmed spectacles, who died in an air crash on 3 February 1959, and who thereby created rock’s very first tragic legend, was much more than simply another 50s rock ‘n’ roll front man who got thrown into unnatural notoriety by his premature death.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/feb/03/buddy-holly-rocker-next-door-classic-profile-nme-1975">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>John Lydon: 'Have I mellowed? Absolutely f***ing not' – a classic interview</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/jan/27/john-lydon-have-i-mellowed-classic-interview-q-1989</link>
      <description><p>We celebrate the former Sex Pistol turning 60 on Sunday with this piece showing him on drunkenly eviscerating form, first published in Q in July 1989 and taken from <a href="http://www.rocksbackpages.com/">Rock’s Backpages</a>, the online home of music writing </p><p>In the bar of the north London rehearsal studio complex, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/oct/18/john-lydon-dyed-hair-brussels-sprout-food-london-childhood-sid-vicious">John Lydon</a>, wearing a typically loud shirt, a pair of unorthodox dark spectacles and the kind of “colourful” straw hat Bob Hope might don for a round of pro-celeb golf, is treating all and sundry to his remarkable impression of an avant-garde lager lout.<br></p><p>I don’t think the English actually read, do they? They just look at the pictures</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/jan/27/john-lydon-have-i-mellowed-classic-interview-q-1989">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Syd Barrett: the genius who almost was – a classic profile by Nick Kent</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/jan/06/nick-kent-pink-floyd-syd-barrett-classic-profile-creem-1973</link>
      <description><p>The late Pink Floyd leader’s 70th birthday is celebrated with Nick Kent’s piece, first published in Creem in October 1973, and taken from Rock’s Backpages, the online home of music writing </p><p>It was only a few months back that a friend told me he’d seen <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/culture/2006/jul/11/sydbarrett.pinkfloyd">Syd Barrett</a> drifting down Charing Cross Road, looking in guitar shops. His hair was long again, and he was back to wearing his old snakeskin boots.<br></p><p> Such a revelation may not mean much to a lot of you, but to hardcore Pink Floyd fanatics, even the <em>possibility </em>of his return is cause enough for celebration. Barrett – the guitarist/songwriter who shaped the early image of Pink Floyd through such vehicles as Arnold Layne, See Emily Play and Interstellar Overdrive – had been in his post-Floyd obscurity the object of a cult-level adoration; a genius who almost was.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/jan/06/nick-kent-pink-floyd-syd-barrett-classic-profile-creem-1973">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/sydbarrett">Syd Barrett</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/music">Music</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/pinkfloyd">Pink Floyd</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/culture">Culture</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/psychedelia">Psychedelia</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/society/mental-health">Mental health</category>

    <item>
      <title>Lemmy: a life in quotes</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/dec/29/lemmy-a-life-in-quotes</link>
      <description><p>From acoustically enhanced pizza to his adoration of hotels and disdain for celibacy, here’s the late metal star’s life in quotes, courtesy of <a href="http://www.rocksbackpages.com/">Rock’s Backpages </a></p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/dec/29/lemmy-lead-singer-of-motorhead-dies-at-70-after-battle-with-cancer">Lemmy, Motörhead frontman, dies at 70</a> </p><p>The School for the Dancing Arts and Education Tring, Hertfordshire, mmmmm! Wonderful. Wonderful. All ballet dancers come down to get a bit of rough. Beautiful women, voluptuous, long legs – beautiful naked women pirouetting round the room, with shawls hanging off the ceiling ... Great stuff. But you can’t do it nowadays; you can’t get the staff. And you don’t seem to be able to get the shawls either.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/dec/29/lemmy-a-life-in-quotes">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>ZZ Top's Billy Gibbons: 'I don’t want to get too eclectic'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/dec/16/zz-top-billy-gibbons-from-rocks-backpages-classic-interview</link>
      <description><p>Billy F Gibbons turns 65 this week. Here’s a classic ZZ Top interview taken from Blast in August 1976 and resurrected by Rock’s Backpages </p><p>ZZ Top don’t exactly carry the image of being introspective, deep-thinking individuals. In fact, on stage they look like nothing other than a bunch of dumb shits from Texas, three boys who just walked off the set of Bonanza<em> </em>and are heading out after the show to eat three sirloins apiece.<br></p><p> But when big <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/nov/05/billy-gibbons-and-the-bfgs-perfectamundo-review-zz-top-guitarist-goes-latin-hip-hop">Billy Gibbons</a> throws down his two-ton spurs and ten-gallon hat, takes off his stacked cowboy boots and removes his padded Nudie suit, behold this rock’n’roll shrimp. He doesn’t even look big enough to hold a flute, never mind play the heaviest guitar made by Gibson, the Les Paul. Hell, this guy is even shorter than <em>me</em>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/dec/16/zz-top-billy-gibbons-from-rocks-backpages-classic-interview">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Dinosaur Jr: 'J Mascis was really into UK Oi! punk – he had a skinhead'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/dec/09/dinosaur-jr-j-mascis-was-really-into-uk-oi-punk-he-had-a-skinhead</link>
      <description><p>As J Mascis, guitarist, singer and grunge icon turns 50, Rock’s Backpages brings you an interview with Dinosaur Jr from Vox magazine in 1991</p><p>J Mascis and Murph, the nuclei of Dinosaur Jr, slouch in their swivel chairs and reiterate their gladness that their next record is coming out on an internationally respected major label. </p><p>“It’s more like a solid foundation,” sighs J. “You know you’re going to be there for a little while; they have money which they’ll probably give to you and they won’t hold out on you. The people I’m dealing with now seem a lot more honourable.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/dec/09/dinosaur-jr-j-mascis-was-really-into-uk-oi-punk-he-had-a-skinhead">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The Prodigy's Liam Howlett: 'We do everything we can to stay off the telly'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/dec/02/from-rocks-backpages-the-prodigy-classic-interview-1994-melody-maker</link>
      <description><p>To mark the Prodigy’s 2015 UK tour, Rock’s Backpages brings you this Melody Maker interview with the band’s frontman. It’s 1994, and the police are killing rave culture …</p><p>“So I’ve decided to take my work back underground … to stop it falling into the wrong hands.” So begins Music for the Jilted Generation, the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2008/aug/01/electronicmusic.alexispetridis">Prodigy</a>’s fab second LP. See, seven consecutive hits and a gold debut album aren’t enough for 23-year-old whiz-kid <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2004/aug/20/popandrock.prodigy">Liam Howlett</a>. He’s sick and tired of his public image: peerless purveyor of hyper-hyper bubblegum nuttercore for E’d up popkids. Liam wants to be taken seriously; more to the point, he wants to be taken seriously by you, the alternative rock fan. So that’s why he’s used rock guitar in a couple of tracks on the album, and that’s why Jilted is a sort of semi-concept album, with a “heavy” political statement.</p><p>“The Jilted Generation, it’s all the kids who’ve grown up on this supposedly corrupt dance music,” says Liam, in between hacking his lungs out (he’s run down by endless remixing and a recent tour of Australia). “The government are trying to make out the whole scene is bad, and they want to stop everyone going out and having a good time.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/dec/02/from-rocks-backpages-the-prodigy-classic-interview-1994-melody-maker">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Diamanda Galás: 'I’ve sung gospel music when in great despair'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/10/diamanda-galas-new-york-interview-red-bull-music-festival</link>
      <description><p>The gothic vocalist is back in New York to bring her latest concept piece to one of Harlem’s most famous churches. Just don’t expect a sermon from her</p><p>Diamanda Galás is going to church this week. As one of the most extreme singers operating today, she favours subject matter that’s found on the dark side of the alleyway. Her work is obsessed with death, disease, fornication, suicide, misery, melancholy, madness and all that other stuff from the Bible.</p><p>Perhaps fittingly, then, the shuttered St Thomas the Apostle church in Harlem will be the site of Galás’s three performances as part of the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/07/dizzee-rascal-boy-in-da-corner-red-bull-music-academy">Red Bull Music Academy festival</a>, which is taking over part of New York City during May. She will present her latest concept piece, Death Will Come, and Will Have Your Eyes.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/10/diamanda-galas-new-york-interview-red-bull-music-festival">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Modern Baseball: meet the band tackling pop-punk’s crude image</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/09/modern-baseball-and-the-bands-changing-pop-punk</link>
      <description><p>A new breed of bands are busting the genre’s juvenile stereotypes and tackling serious subjects like loss and depression</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/quiz/2015/jan/27/popandrock-punk">How well do you know Blink-182? Test your pop-punk knowledge</a> </p><p>Pop-punk has long had a reputation as the male-dominated genre of choice for angsty teenagers who love pizza and hate their parents. The younger cousin of “real punk”, its petulant image means that it tends to be marginalised by critics. Yet its popularity has is on the rise once more. In the UK, for example, its torchbearers are selling out Wembley Arena (Baltimore’s All Time Low) and punching into the albums Top 10 (Wrexham’s Neck Deep).</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/09/modern-baseball-and-the-bands-changing-pop-punk">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Bat For Lashes: 'Even in Sex And The City, the single girls end up with someone'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/07/natasha-khan-bat-for-lashes-new-album-the-bride</link>
      <description><p>Natasha Khan is back, playing a doomed bride and confronting marriage norms on her new album. Sometimes it’s about romancing yourself instead, she explains</p><p>Perched on the pews of a church in Koreatown, Los Angeles, a smartly dressed congregation is watching an unusual marriage ceremony unfold. Natasha Khan is gliding up the aisle, red gown trailing behind her, alone. There’s a black lace veil covering her eyes and her head is lowered, as the music that signals <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TP_wx0qrKu0">The Wizard Of Oz’s Glinda the Good Witch</a> floats out of the speakers. But there’s no groom, only a small cluster of instruments and a candlelit pulpit. “Welcome to my wedding,” she says, almost wryly. But when she lifts her veil and swipes her <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XYIUwlMVS8E">Omnichord</a>, her diamond-sharp falsetto cutting through stark new song I Do, tears are visible in her eyes.</p><p>Khan is better known as the musician Bat For Lashes but tonight her guise is the titular leading lady of her next album, The Bride. Her alter ego isn’t exactly living the fairytale. The album’s elaborate narrative details how the bride is abandoned at the altar, her fiance killed on his way there. Devastated, she speeds off in the honeymoon car and embarks on a dusty road trip of self-discovery. As album concepts go, it’s bold, even batshit; another new song, Close Encounters, she confides, is about “making love to someone from the other side”.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/07/natasha-khan-bat-for-lashes-new-album-the-bride">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Kaytranada: ‘I prefer a house party vibe. Just the local place to have fun’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/05/kaytranada-99-9-xl-recordings-interview</link>
      <description>The top-flight remixer is in constant demand as a DJ. But it’s his first LP, featuring Vic Mensa, Syd tha Kyd and Anderson Paak that could make him a star in his own right. Not that he sounds thrilled about it...    <br /><br /><p>You wouldn’t call Kaytranada an expert salesman of his music. “To be honest, I don’t know,” he says when asked about his hopes for his debut album, 99.9%. “I really hope people create memories and have good times with it. But if they don’t like it, it’s whatever, there’s other things they can listen to.”</p><p>It’s not quite what you expect. After all, 99.9% is packed with guest appearances from 2016’s hottest – <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/aug/04/vic-mensa-rapper-kanye-west-protege" title="">Vic Mensa</a>, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/10/anderson-paak-interview-malibu-dr-dre" title="">Anderson Paak</a>, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/dec/17/syd-tha-kyd-odd-future-the-internet-cuss-words" title="">Syd tha Kyd</a>, as well as the year’s comeback hero, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/sep/14/craig-david-revival-comeback-bbc-blog" title="">Craig David</a>. It’s released on the none-more-cool XL Recordings. It follows a string of remixes that have established him as one of music’s most imaginative manipulators of sound, repurposing scores of artists, including MIA, Beyoncé, Missy Elliott, Azealia Banks, Disclosure, Pharrell Williams and Janet Jackson – both officially and unofficially – as well as production work with <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2011/dec/21/new-band-internet-odd-future" title="">the Internet</a>, Anderson Paak, Katy B, Talib Kweli, Freddie Gibbs and many others.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/05/kaytranada-99-9-xl-recordings-interview">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Lenny Henry on his music career: ‘I had Jeremy Paxman getting down to Sex Machine’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2016/may/05/lenny-henry-music-career-blues-racism-prince</link>
      <description><p>The comedian turned singer on police racism, finding humour in the blues and what he learned from his hero, Prince</p><p><strong>Hi Lenny! You’ve just put out a blues album, </strong><a href="https://www.amazon.co.uk/NEW-MILLENNIUM-BLUES-Lenny-Henry/dp/B014GLTRGQ"><strong>New Millennium Blues</strong></a><strong>. What is it with comedians and the blues (1) ? </strong></p><p>The blues has been in my life since I was little. My parents had this massive record player in the living room, a “blue spot grand” they called it ... it used up an entire rainforest to make this thing, and it had all these records in it. Some were rock, some were reggae, but a lot was blues – <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/raycharles">Ray Charles</a>, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/chuck-berry">Chuck Berry</a> and all that stuff.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2016/may/05/lenny-henry-music-career-blues-racism-prince">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Teddy Thompson and Kelly Jones: 'If musicians disappear, the music will too'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/05/teddy-thompson-kelly-jones-musicians-little-windows</link>
      <description><p>What do you do when you’re fed up of modern pop and worrying how to make a living? You make a record summoning the spirit of 1962</p><p>If you play an acoustic guitar, and can draw a crowd of 300 or so, each of whom has a few dollars to spare, then the chances are that when you visit New York you will be playing at the City Winery. Which is where, on a bitterly cold April night, Teddy Thompson and Kelly Jones - not the one from Stereophonics – are on stage. </p><p>It’s a curious venue. Not least because it’s also a restaurant. The crowd are all seated at tables, some finishing their dinner, others hoping against hope that at some point a member of staff might pass and they can actually order a drink. Everyone has to twist awkwardly to watch, or scrape their chairs against the floor to turn and face the stage. It’s against this backdrop that Thompson and Jones gamely press ahead with a set drawn largely from their album of duets, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2016/jan/05/the-playlist-folk-world-music-rokia-traore-teddy-thompson">Little Windows</a>, on which the pair sing songs, all written themselves, in the style of the pop of the late 50s and early 60s: think the Brill Building, the Everly Brothers, Buddy Holly. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/05/teddy-thompson-kelly-jones-musicians-little-windows">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>From lad to lover, the story of LUH</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/04/luh-lost-under-heaven-ellery-roberts-ebony-hoorn</link>
      <description><p>After deserting his lad band Wu Lyf, Ellery Roberts was lost and in trouble. Then Ebony Hoorn appeared in his Manchester squat</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/mar/09/luh-review-electrowerkz-london-wu-lyf-ellery-roberts">LUH review – former Wu Lyf frontman delivers anthems for the angry</a> </p><p>Four years ago, Ellery Roberts was at a low ebb. His enigmatic, publicity courting music project Wu Lyf had been unmasked as just another four-piece lad band, and he was living in an abandoned Manchester terrace, writing aggressive, joyless songs about the capitalist machine. But his life was about to be transformed. Returning home one day, he found Ebony Hoorn sitting at his kitchen table. A student of art at Holland’s Gerrit Rietveld Academie, she was visiting a friend in the same squat. The pair shared “a really intense connection” and within a few months had shacked up together in a converted hospital in Amsterdam.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/04/luh-lost-under-heaven-ellery-roberts-ebony-hoorn">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>How we made: Donovan's Sunshine Superman</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2016/may/02/how-we-made-sunshine-superman-donovan</link>
      <description><p>‘It’s primarily a love song – but I was also trying to get to the invisible fourth dimension of transcendental superconscious vision’</p><p><a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LGLcXIrk6S0">Sunshine Superman</a> was one of the first British psychedelic records, but it’s primarily a love song. It was the mid-60s and I was appearing on <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/aug/19/how-we-made-ready-steady-go">Ready Steady Go!</a>, playing <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J8hjEYTpwE8">Catch the Wind</a>, when I saw this girl. I said to my mate <a href="http://www.gypmillssculptures.com/">Gypsy Dave</a>: “My God, look at that girl. She’s beautiful.” We had a dance. She told me her name was Linda Lawrence and I was absolutely smitten.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2016/may/02/how-we-made-sunshine-superman-donovan">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Brix Smith Start: ‘Mark E Smith? He’s complicated’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/01/brix-smith-start-interview-rise-fall-rise-mark-e-smith-nigel-kennedy-philip-start-the-extricated</link>
      <description><p>Ex-Fall guitarist Brix Smith Start endured wild and colourful marriages with both Mark E Smith and Nigel Kennedy. Now she’s written her memoir… </p><p>In May 1983, Brix Smith, then aged 20, arrived in Manchester. A Californian by birth and disposition, her first impressions of the city were not favourable. The buildings, she writes in her entertainingly bonkers memoir, <em>The Rise, the Fall and the Rise</em>, “looked like mean structures where horrible atrocities had been committed”. The sky was “toxic”, the people were “joyless”, their clothes “drab”.</p><p>As a taxi took her towards Prestwich, where the man she had fallen for just six weeks earlier lived, he pointed out the local landmarks: “Look, Brixie, there’s the Boddingtons brewery! There’s Strangeways prison!” Entering the lobby of his building, she was struck by the dirt on the walls and the “strong odour of urine”. In his flat, there were cats everywhere and items of unwashed underwear belonging to his ex-girlfriend. As they sat down for a cuppa, he reached out on to the window ledge for the pint of milk that sat there alongside a pack of back bacon, a carton of eggs and a Hovis loaf. “I was incredulous,” she writes. “Perhaps this was a traditional resourceful British custom.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/01/brix-smith-start-interview-rise-fall-rise-mark-e-smith-nigel-kennedy-philip-start-the-extricated">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Candi Staton: ‘My biggest disappointment? Choosing the wrong mate’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/apr/30/candi-staton-singer-interview-biggest-disappointment</link>
      <description><p>The singer on her early memories, an embarrassing awards moment and wanting to be a young heart running free</p><p>Born in Alabama, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/culture/2012/apr/17/candi-staton-singer">Candi Staton</a>, 76, began singing in a Baptist church at the age of five. Her hits include the disco anthems <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/culture/2015/jun/30/candi-staton-how-we-made-young-hearts-run-free">Young Hearts Run Free</a>, first released in 1976, and 1986’s <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/nov/28/florence-machine-you-got-the-love">You Got The Love</a>. In June, she appears at <a href="http://underthebridge.co.uk/events/candi-staton/">Under The Bridge in London as part of her Young Hearts Run Free 40th anniversary tour</a>. She&nbsp;has been married five times and lives in Atlanta.</p><p><br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/apr/30/candi-staton-singer-interview-biggest-disappointment">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/music">Music</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/lifeandstyle">Life and style</category>

    <item>
      <title>Richard Ashcroft: ‘I wouldn’t trade what Coldplay have achieved for any of my songs'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/28/richard-ashcroft-i-wouldnt-trade-what-coldplay-have-achieved-for-any-of-my-songs</link>
      <description><p>From careering around Wigan in his mate’s Mini to posing with a drip in his arm, the former Mad Richard has had a breakneck ride. He may now be living a quieter life but he still wants to be ‘bigger than the Verve’</p><p>“The way we and our mates were living back then was crazy,” says Richard Ashcroft, remembering the days he was on the precipice of fame before the Verve’s third album, Urban Hymns, made them ubiquitous in 1997. “A scene in This is England brought it home. Shane Meadows faded in on this girl’s retina. It’s five in the morning, she’s watching some lads play a video game. She’s obviously wasted, and that shot just sums that period up. I feel lucky I got out alive.”</p><p>The Verve had blazed out of the north-west, a product of both rave culture and psychedelia. Ashcroft, wild-eyed and shaggy-haired, was a man prone to ridiculous pronouncements who inspired incredible loyalty. Noel Gallager wrote the Oasis song Cast No Shadow about him and Chris Martin introduced him at Live 8 as “the best singer in the world” while the music mags nicknamed him “Mad Richard” after he claimed he could fly. If there’s an image of Ashcroft fixed in the public mind, it comes from the video for the Verve’s breakthrough single, Bitter Sweet Symphony which featured Ashcroft walking down a street, while everyone else walks the other way, his eyes fixed on the camera refusing to be pushed from his path. “Try to make ends meet / You’re a slave to the money / Then you die,” he sang.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/28/richard-ashcroft-i-wouldnt-trade-what-coldplay-have-achieved-for-any-of-my-songs">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Todd Snider finds Rest in Chaos: 'When I take hallucinogens it’s usually for work'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/todd-snider-hard-working-americans-rest-in-chaos-new-album</link>
      <description><p>The alternative country star has a new psychedelic jam band, Hard Working Americans – and he’s still retained the respect of Nashville’s old guard</p><p>Long before <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/jack-white">Jack White</a> and the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/14/black-keys-steve-miller-rock-and-roll-hall-of-fame">Black Keys </a>hit Nashville, <a href="http://www.toddsnider.net/">Todd Snider </a>was a one-man alternative in music city, releasing his debut album Songs for the Daily Planet in 1994. Since then he has carved out his own niche as a storyteller with a wit to rival <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2005/nov/04/popandrock3">John Prine</a>, the folk heart of early Bob Dylan and the ragged glory of the Rolling Stones. His songs have earned him respect from all corners of country music, from <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/jul/29/garth-brooks-country-music-rich-list-earning-90m-past-year">Garth Brooks</a> to <a href="http://www.jerryjeff.com/bash/">Jerry Jeff Walker</a> to <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/jul/28/jason-isbell-country-music-radio">Jason Isbell</a>.</p><p>He also has a new band, <a href="http://www.thehardworkingamericans.com/">Hard Working Americans</a>, including members of <a href="http://www.widespreadpanic.com/">Widespread Panic</a> and psych band the <a href="http://chrisrobinsonbrotherhood.com/">Chris Robinson Brotherhood</a>. Together they released <a href="http://www.jambase.com/article/hard-working-americans-announce-new-album-rest-in-chaos">Rest in Chaos</a>, their first set of original songs and this spring they are on the jam band circuit, a new environment for Snider, known for his troubadour spirit. For now, he says, he’s focused on getting people dancing. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/12/todd-snider-hard-working-americans-rest-in-chaos-new-album">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Ash Koosha: 'I try to avoid any indication that I’m doing anything political'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/10/ash-koosha-interview-i-aka-i-iran-london</link>
      <description><p>The Iranian-born, London-based musician is taking futurism to new levels on his album, I AKA I. He talks with the Guardian about his past at the Tehran Conservatory of Music and his present in exile</p><p>Ashkan Kooshanejad is obsessed with the future. In conversation, it seems like he has already been there. The London-based, Tehran-born artist, known as Ash Koosha, talks of a world where iPhones are embedded below our skin, where humans take agency over digital existence, where our devices will be a part of us and we will be a part of them. “This is happening,” he says. “But we kind of ignore it.” Koosha sees a future where a universal basic income will be paid to all, alleviating the economic inequality that rapid technological advances are creating. And music, well, music might not actually exist any more. But it’s nothing to be scared of.</p><p>“Technophobia is not relevant any more,” says Koosha, whose second full-length record I AKA I is out now on Ninja Tune, following his 2015 debut, GUUD, on Olde English Spelling Bee. “Because the human that I am, at its core, is also in that digital version of myself. It’s just me. It’s I, also known as, I.” Koosha makes meticulous electronic music, employing what he calls “nano-compositions” made from manipulated field recordings, and channeling an inherent influence of Iranian groove. He is a musician, a multimedia experimenter, a film-maker. But most of all, he is a philosopher, whose art works to find intimacy and humanity in digital culture; meditating on how the technological singularity, the future when we could become outsmarted by machines, will impact our humanness and our capacity for expression. “The future of humanity is generally a subject I live with every day. I think about it, I talk to my friends about it. When I’m doing music, it naturally comes out. It’s a part of my emotions.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/10/ash-koosha-interview-i-aka-i-iran-london">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Kevin Rowland: ‘I’ve expressed myself in the way I wanted’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/08/kevin-rowland-dexys-ive-expressed-myself-the-way-i-wanted</link>
      <description><p>Soon to release a cover album of his favourite songs, the Dexys frontman talks about his Irish roots, his grudges – and why he wore a dress for Reading 1999</p><p>I meet Kevin Rowland for lunch in his local vegan restaurant in east London. He is dressed down today, at least by his often extravagant sartorial standards, in buttoned-up denim shirt, wide denim jeans and a large flat cap. The look, from the stripy fisherman’s jumper draped over his shoulders to his well-groomed ’tache and goatee, is bohemian, rather than full-on dandy. He seems relaxed and looks tanned and healthy.</p><p>“Yeah, I feel all right,” he says, smiling, “but I do have to work at it. I’ve made an album exactly how I wanted to. I’ve expressed myself in the way I wanted.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/08/kevin-rowland-dexys-ive-expressed-myself-the-way-i-wanted">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/05/james-blake-beyonce-kanye-west-colour-in-anything</link>
      <description><p>Kanye, Beyoncé, Drake and Frank Ocean have all been inspired by the unassuming Londoner’s sound. Now he’s coming of age with his new album, The Colour in Anything</p><p>A few months ago, James Blake was working on the biggest album of 2016 and he couldn’t tell anyone. Beyoncé had asked him to come to the studio and work on the secrecy-shrouded Lemonade. After he’d been improvising for a while around her melodies and lyrical ideas, Beyoncé arrived with her four-year-old daughter Blue Ivy to hear what he had come up with. Every time he sang the hook on the song Forward, Blue Ivy sang: “Forward!”</p><p>“That’s how you know it’s catchy,” Beyoncé told him.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/05/james-blake-beyonce-kanye-west-colour-in-anything">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>'All right Reading!' – test your knowledge of the Reading and Leeds festivals with our fiendish quiz</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/aug/28/all-right-reading-test-your-knowledge-of-the-reading-and-leeds-festivals-with-our-fiendish-quiz</link>
      <description><p>With the rocktastic festivals taking place this weekend, it’s time to see how much you know about their history</p><p>The 1988 Reading festival saw the bill divided between MOR rock bands and more indie-friendly acts, resulting in tensions that led to two acts’ sets interrupted by a hail of bottles from the crowd.     <item>
      <title>Guess the guitar hero – from their guitar</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/jul/28/guess-the-guitar-hero-from-their-guitar</link>
      <description><p>We’ve cut out the faces of 12 axemen with distinctive guitars, so you have to identify the guitarist from their instrument …</p><p>1It’s a sharp dressed guitar – but is its fluffiness signifying the kind of owner who might drive a souped-up Cortina with fluffy dice and a bit of jazz funk on the stereo? <a>Boon Gould of Level 42</a><a>Eddie Hazel of Funkadelic</a><a>Billy Gibbons of ZZ Top</a><a>Johnny Marr of the Smiths</a>2Quite the eruption of colour from this one, sported by which Californian?<a> Eddie van Halen of Van Halen</a><a>Carlos Santana of Santana</a><a>Mick Mars of Mötley Crüe</a><a>Greg Ginn of Black Flag</a>3In later years he’d substitute the classic Rickenbacker for a selection of Gibsons. Which art school boy is this?<a>Ray Davies of the Kinks</a><a>John Lennon of the Beatles</a><a>Syd Barrett of Pink Floyd</a><a>Pete Townshend of the Who</a>4He’s British and he’s proud of it! But which Britpop king flew the flag?<a>Graham Coxon of Blur</a><a>Mark Webber of Pulp</a><a>Noel Gallagher of Oasis</a><a>Chris Gentry of Menswear</a>5The battered Telecaster is, naturally, the guitar of the common man. Which common man, though?<a>Frank Turner</a><a>Billy Bragg</a><a>Bruce Springsteen</a><a>Tom Clarke of the Enemy</a>6You can’t mistake this guitar, even in a little silhouette. Who’s playing it?<a>Brian May of Queen</a><a>Jimmy Page of Led Zeppelin</a><a>Steve Howe of Yes</a><a>Jeff Lynne of ELO</a>7Five necks good, one neck bad. Is it five times more expensive for its owner?<a>Paul Stanley of Kiss</a><a>Rick Neilsen of Cheap Trick</a><a>Donald Roeser of Blue Öyster Cult</a><a>Tom Scholz of Boston</a>8It’s the Flying V’s owner we’re looking for, but the presence of a “twin guitar attack” should give you a clue who’s sporting it …<a>Scott Gorham of Thin Lizzy</a><a>Michael Schenker of UFO</a><a>Kirk Hammett of Metallica</a><a>KK Downing of Judas Priest</a>9The guitar’s square. The man most certainly wasn’t. Who’s pictured?<a>Bo Diddley</a><a>BB King</a><a>Billy Gibbons of ZZ Top</a><a>Howlin’ Wolf</a>10Name the man who wrote a song so profound it needed not six, not 12, but 18 strings to play.<a>Pete Townshend of the Who</a><a>Keith Richards of the Rolling Stones</a><a>Jimmy Page of Led Zeppelin</a><a>Alex Lifeson of Rush</a>11You don’t get to be as heavy as this man by playing guitars with soft, rounded edges. Who is more metallic than thou?<a>Dave Murray of Iron Maiden</a><a>James Hetfield of Metallica</a><a>Kerry King of Slayer</a><a>Dave Mustaine of Megadeth</a>12And finally, if you don’t get this one, consider yourself told off. Just consider the fact that the SG-playing guitarist is wearing school uniform …<a>Tom Morello of Rage Against the Machine</a><a>Brian “Head” Welch of Korn</a><a>Wes Borland of Limp Bizkit</a><a>Angus Young of AC/DC</a></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/jul/28/guess-the-guitar-hero-from-their-guitar">Continue reading...</a></description>
