    <item>
      <title>Test your knowledge of bands in fiction – quiz</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/books/quiz/2015/jun/24/bands-in-fiction-quiz-glastonbury</link>
      <description>For those of us avoiding Glastonbury mud in favour of reading in a nice dry room, there are still plenty of rock thrills available in the library. Find out if you're a headline act or bottom of the bill<p class="question__text">What’s the name of the group with Beatles haircuts who sing in fake British accents in Thomas Pynchon’s The Crying of Lot 49?</p><p class="answer__text">The Paranoids</p><p class="answer__text">The Monkees</p><p class="answer__text">The Androids</p><p class="answer__text">The Merseymen</p><p class="question__text">Which of these bands did NOT take their name from A Clockwork Orange by Anthony Burgess?</p><p class="answer__text">Heaven 17</p><p class="answer__text">Moloko</p><p class="answer__text">Level 42</p><p class="answer__text">Campag Velocet</p><p class="question__text">“I wish I could hit upon a pleasant track of thought, a track indirectly reflecting credit upon myself, for those are the pleasantest thoughts, and very frequent even in the minds of modest, mouse-coloured people, who believe genuinely that they dislike to hear their own praises.” This passage inspired the band name Modest Mouse, but where does it come from?</p><p class="answer__text">The Yellow Wallpaper by Charlotte Perkins Gilman</p><p class="answer__text">The Mark on the Wall by Virginia Woolf</p><p class="answer__text">Jane Eyre by Charlotte Brontë</p><p class="answer__text">Hotel du Lac by Anita Brookner</p><p class="question__text">“I'd like to introduce you to the hardest-workin' band in the world. On bass, Derek ‘Meatman’ Scully. On piano, Steven ‘Soul Surgeon’ Clifford. Dean ‘Mr Nipple’ Fay on sax. Joey ‘The Lips’ Fagan on trumpet. Our gorgeous chanteuses are Bernie, Imelda, and Natalie. Deco ‘Deep Throat’ Cuffe on vocals. On lead guitar, Outspan ‘Fender bender’ Foster. Finally, on drums, Mickah ‘Don't Fuck With Me’ Wallace…” In which book does this fictional group appear?</p><p class="answer__text">Espedair Street by Iain Banks</p><p class="answer__text">City of Bohane by Kevin Barry</p><p class="answer__text">Powder by Kevin Sampson</p><p class="answer__text">The Commitments by Roddy Doyle</p><p class="question__text">In Don DeLillo’s Great Jones Street, the newly reclusive rock star Bucky Wunderlick renounces his career and refuses to release which recordings?</p><p class="answer__text">The Basement Tapes</p><p class="answer__text">The Mountain Tapes</p><p class="answer__text">The East Village Tapes</p><p class="answer__text">The Bootleg Tapes</p><p class="question__text">In Jonathan Franzen’s Freedom, Richard finally achieves musical success in middle age. What’s the name of his hit album?</p><p class="answer__text">Nameless Lake</p><p class="answer__text">Nameless Sparrow</p><p class="answer__text">Nameless Ennui</p><p class="answer__text">The Great American Album</p><p class="question__text">Steely Dan drew their insalubrious name from which notorious novel?</p><p class="answer__text">Lady Chatterley’s Lover by DH Lawrence</p><p class="answer__text">The Naked Lunch by William Burroughs</p><p class="answer__text">The Lover by Marguerite Duras</p><p class="answer__text">Bend Sinister by Vladimir Nabokov</p><p class="question__text">Hopeful 80s punk band The Flaming Dildos appear in which novel?</p><p class="answer__text">I Play the Drums in a Band Called okay by Toby Litt</p><p class="answer__text">Juliet, Naked by Nick Hornby</p><p class="answer__text">A Visit from the Goon Squad by Jennifer Egan</p><p class="answer__text">The Thrill of It All by Joseph O’Connor</p><p class="question__text">In Sherman Alexie’s Reservation Blues, which legendary blues singer makes a guest appearance at the Spokane reservation?</p><p class="answer__text">Robert Johnson</p><p class="answer__text">Bessie Smith</p><p class="answer__text">BB King</p><p class="answer__text">Muddy Waters</p><p class="question__text">What’s the name of the wandering minstrel who features in George RR Martin’s A Song of Ice and Fire books?</p><p class="answer__text">Yan Smoothtongue</p><p class="answer__text">Marillion</p><p class="answer__text">True B’Adour</p><p class="answer__text">Captain Sensible</p><p class="question__text">Salman Rushdie’s The Ground Beneath Her Feet provided lyrics for which real-life band?</p><p class="answer__text">U2</p><p class="answer__text">Coldplay</p><p class="answer__text">REM</p><p class="answer__text">Outkast</p><p class="question__text">In indie music, they’re giants. In literature, Belle and Sebastian are …</p><p class="answer__text">Names of two of the children in Emil and the Detectives</p><p class="answer__text">Star-crossed lovers in Dante’s Divine Comedy</p><p class="answer__text">A boy and his dog living in an Alpine village in a classic French novel</p><p class="answer__text">Warriors pursuing a bloody feud with the murderous Foo Fighters </p><p class="score__min-score">2 and above.</p><p class="score__title">Pitiful. A performance worthy of Spinal Tap. We're laughing at you.</p><p class="score__min-score">4 and above.</p><p class="score__title">A moderate success, but not that great. You're the Dream Syndicate of this quiz</p><p class="score__min-score">7 and above.</p><p class="score__title">Not bad, but don't expect five stars from Alexis Petridis</p><p class="score__min-score">10 and above.</p><p class="score__title">A star performance – you rock!</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/books/quiz/2015/jun/24/bands-in-fiction-quiz-glastonbury">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/glastonbury-2015">Glastonbury 2015</category>

      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/books/quiz/2015/jun/24/bands-in-fiction-quiz-glastonbury</guid>

    <item>

      <description><p>English National Opera this week opens a new production of Philip Glass’s Akhnaten, his 1983 opera about the ancient Egyptian pharaoh. Tristram Kenton went along to rehearsals to capture the creation of what looks set to be a stunning production.</p><p><a href="https://www.eno.org/whats-on/akhnaten/">Akhnaten is at the Coliseum, London, from 4 to 18 March</a>.<br></p><p><em>All photographs: Tristram Kenton for the Guardian</em><br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/gallery/2016/mar/01/behind-the-scenes-philip-glass-akhnaten-eno-in-pictures">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Yoko Ono: 'I thought my music was beautiful all along'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/feb/22/yoko-ono-interview-i-thought-my-music-was-beautiful-all-along</link>
      <description><p>She was subjected to decades of vilification. Now everyone from Gaga to Sparks are lining up to pay tribute. How does the 83-year-old artist feel about the world catching up to the Yoko Ono sound?</p><p>Yoko Ono is giving me a demonstration of her vocal technique. Almost half a century after it was first unleashed on an unsuspecting British public – at a 1968 <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/jun/11/ornette-coleman">Ornette Coleman</a> concert at the Royal Albert Hall, while John Lennon was away in India with the Maharishi – it’s still a hair-raising experience, particularly when it’s happening a few feet away from your face. In fact, it’s all the more so because the demonstration is interspersed with Ono’s explanation of how she came upon her unique approach to vocals, and Yoko Ono’s speaking voice is incredibly soft and delicate – not adjectives anyone is ever going to apply to her singing.</p><p>It all started when she was a little girl, she says: her family were wealthy, they had maids, “and my mother said: ‘Don’t you ever go to the servants’ rooms, it’s very bad, because they’re talking about things you don’t want to know.’ And sure enough, I just sneaked up and listened to it. And these two teenage girls, they were combing their hair and talking. ‘My aunt had a baby yesterday.’ ‘Oh, really?’ ‘Yes, and she was making noises.’”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/feb/22/yoko-ono-interview-i-thought-my-music-was-beautiful-all-along">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/music">Music</category>

      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/culture">Culture</category>

      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/lifeandstyle">Life and style</category>
      <pubDate>Mon, 22 Feb 2016 19:00:16 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/feb/22/yoko-ono-interview-i-thought-my-music-was-beautiful-all-along</guid>

    <item>
      <title>Class act: why working-class voices are music to Darkstar's ears</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/dec/03/darkstar-huddersfield-panic-social-mobility-foam-island-album-interview</link>
      <description><p>Why did these two men hang around Huddersfield railway station asking young people what they did today? Electronic duo Darkstar explain their most daring LP yet</p><p>“We just said to people: ‘We want your life in a nutshell. What do you do every day? What did you dream about last night? What have you been doing for work? And we asked people if they were going to vote – and if not, why not?”</p><p>James Young, 33, is sitting alongside his creative partner Aiden Whalley, 31, in the cafe of London’s Barbican, where they are preparing for the first of their two events in a season titled <a href="http://www.barbican.org.uk/film/series.asp?ID=1540">Panic! What Happened to Social Mobility in the Arts?</a> It is intended to shine a light on the apparently narrowing range of voices in the arts, and what seems to be an increasing middle-class monopoly. The pair make music as Darkstar, and their latest album is something of a case study in what Panic! is meant to highlight. Titled <a href="http://warp.net/releases/darkstar-foam-island/">Foam Island</a>, it’s an impossibly evocative portrait of the everyday lives of teenagers and twentysomethings in <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/uk/huddersfield">Huddersfield</a>, West Yorkshire, recorded in the build-up to this year’s <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/may/08/david-cameron-conservative-government-election-victory">general election</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/dec/03/darkstar-huddersfield-panic-social-mobility-foam-island-album-interview">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/music">Music</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/society/socialmobility">Social mobility</category>

    <item>
      <title>Groupies revisited: the women with triple-A access to the 60s</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/nov/15/groupies-revisited-baron-wolman-rolling-stone-pamela-des-barres</link>
      <description><p>In 1969, <em>Rolling Stone</em> shocked the world with an issue about the rock ‘supergroupie’. As a book about that moment is published, photographer Baron Wolman and veteran groupie Pamela des Barres tell all</p><p>‘She got her man. He was the cat they all were after and she got him!... in the culture of rock and roll that makes her something. She had already balled 17 (or 36 or 117) musicians – four (or 12 or 25) of them real stars, names everybody would know – but now her status was elevated again.”</p><p>So begins a 14,000-word article in a “Special Super-Duper Neat Issue” issue of <em>Rolling Stone</em> magazine in 1969, which introduced the wider world to the phenomenon of the rock groupie. The scandalous issue explored the difference between groupies and the inferior “star-fuckers”; group sex; the advantages of amyl nitrate; even a lubricious letter from an eight-year-old girl to the Grateful Dead’s Jerry Garcia – and ushered in a wave of articles, books and documentaries about groupies.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/nov/15/groupies-revisited-baron-wolman-rolling-stone-pamela-des-barres">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Keith Richards: ‘You don’t stop growing until they shovel the dirt in’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/sep/17/keith-richards-you-dont-stop-growing-until-they-shovel-the-dirt-in</link>
      <description><p>At 71, the Rolling Stones legend is proud of his cartoon image as a rock outlaw. He’s back now with his first solo album in 23 years. But some days, the wildman reputation feels like a ball and chain – he just wants to visit an art gallery or water the garden </p><p>There are few things in life that make you feel more pathetic than smoking an e-cigarette in front of Keith Richards. I know this because I’m puffing on one when he sways into his suite at the Savoy in central London, looking, I’m delighted to report, like a caricature of Keith Richards come to life. Smouldering Marlboro in one hand, glass in the other, shirt open, tight black jeans encasing legs so skinny you wonder how they support the rest of him, slight though the rest of him is. For all that people go on about the wrinkles on his face, Richards’ physique is a walking advert for the benefits of a diet he claims is largely composed of “meat and potatoes”, vodka and orange, and nicotine: “No, I don’t work out. No, no, no. I mean, I pick up those things” – he mimes lifting a dumbbell – “and go: ‘God, that’s too heavy.’ Then put them down.”</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/sep/17/keith-richards-crosseyed-heart-review">Keith Richards: Crosseyed Heart review – everything a fan could hope for</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/sep/17/keith-richards-you-dont-stop-growing-until-they-shovel-the-dirt-in">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Young Thug: 'I like everything people say about me – you gay, you a punk, you can't rap, you're the hardest'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/oct/08/young-thug-hits-bring-money-lil-wayne</link>
      <description><p>Atlanta’s Young Thug is the gender-fluid, surrealist rapper who’s being anointed as hip-hop’s next titan. Don’t know what to make of him? You’re not the only one</p><p>The morning Young Thug is due to play his first headline show in London, another American rapper is making headlines. Tyler, the Creator has been <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2015/sep/01/tyler-the-creator-comments-banned-uk-freedom-of-speech">banned from the UK by home secretary Theresa May</a>, apparently because he “made statements that may foster hatred, which might lead to intercommunity violence in the UK”.</p><p>Meanwhile, Young Thug was gliding across the border on the Eurostar from Paris, without so much as a pat-down. Whereas Tyler is a geeky rapper who has never been charged with a serious crime in his life, Young Thug <a href="http://www.tmz.com/2015/07/16/young-thug-drugs-weapons-charges-police-raid/">had his home raided</a> in July after he allegedly threatened to kill a mall security guard in Georgia. During the raid, police found guns, cocaine and marijuana and he was hit with three counts of felony arms possession. That all happened on the same day an indictment was issued claiming that Thug, along with his label boss at Cash Money Records, Birdman, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/jul/16/young-thug-accused-of-orchestrating-shooting-of-lil-waynes-tour-bus">conspired to have Thug’s hero and mentor Lil Wayne murdered</a> (a charge he strenuously denies).</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/oct/08/young-thug-hits-bring-money-lil-wayne">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Blur: 'We used to take it in turns to punch each other'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/jul/30/blur-interview-magic-whip-hong-kong</link>
      <description><p>Back in Hong Kong, where they recorded their album The Magic Whip, Damon, Graham, Alex and Dave talk about falling out and making up, the state of British pop music and why 90s Britpop was a wasted opportunity</p><p>Hong Kong in July can be a disorientating place for outsiders: the suffocating humidity, the density of human bodies, the mind-jarring collision of east and west. Perhaps the last thing you need when you’ve arrived there, brain fuddled with jetlag, is a conversation with Damon Albarn in full manic flow. One minute he’s talking about refusing to <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/jul/06/damon-albarn-roskilde-carried-off-stage-following-five-hour-set-africa-express">leave the stage after a five-hour gig</a> with Africa Express (“Am I addicted to work? Clearly”), the next he’s revealing his passion for picking wild flowers. Then he starts talking about fairies ...</p><p>“I’ve a house that’s built on a piece of land which was a recognised fairy community,” he says, with a straight face, when we meet backstage at the Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Centre, where Blur are due to play that night. “We had to get a fairy lawyer in. When people come and stay at my house, they go and give them an offering just to keep them happy because we’ve built on their land.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/jul/30/blur-interview-magic-whip-hong-kong">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Amy Winehouse, my sister and addiction</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/global/2015/jul/07/amy-winehouse-my-addict-sister</link>
      <description><p>Amy being alive meant there was hope for my heroin-addicted younger sister. When the singer died, my world caved in. What chance did we have now?<br></p><p>I remember where I was the day that Amy Winehouse died. I had run into a shop in Soho to buy a birthday present, when I heard an exchange between the girl at the till and her customer. “She died of an overdose. It was just on the radio,” the cashier said in a “sad news” voice while counting out the change. Both shook their heads, tutting, saying “what a waste” and other stock phrases that people keep in reserve for when the talented die young.</p><p>Whenever there’s mention of Amy – which is often at the moment because, with <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/jul/02/amy-winehouse-review-documentary">this new film</a>, she’s suddenly everywhere again – the same feeling is dredged up from a crevasse in my guts. The sucker punch that gave me jelly legs. The way my mouth went slack and dry. The fact that my teeth chattered even though it was July.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/global/2015/jul/07/amy-winehouse-my-addict-sister">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Tales from the vault: what we've learned about Prince since he died</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/shortcuts/2016/may/11/prince-unplugged-celibacy-ping-pong-chocolate-fountains</link>
      <description><p>In life Prince was deeply private; in death, his acquaintances have been sharing anecdotes about everything from his skill at ping-pong to his JFK conspiracy theories </p><p>In a previously <a href="http://www.rollingstone.com/music/features/a-final-visit-with-prince-rolling-stones-lost-cover-story-20160502">unpublished interview with Rolling Stone from 2014</a>, he aligned himself with Aids and JFK conspiracy theorists (“the car slows down – why doesn’t it speed up?”). He also revealed that he fasted for days on end (“after four days, you don’t want food any more”), was celibate and something of a feminist (“most men don’t know how to listen”).<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/shortcuts/2016/may/11/prince-unplugged-celibacy-ping-pong-chocolate-fountains">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Beyoncé's Lemonade is capitalist money-making at its best</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/11/capitalism-of-beyonce-lemonade-album</link>
      <description><p>From slavery to the present, black female bodies have been bought and sold. What makes this commodification different in Lemonade is intent – its purpose is to seduce</p><p>Fresh lemonade is my drink of choice. In my small Kentucky town, beautiful black, brown and white girls set up their lemonade stands and practice the art of money-making – it’s business. As a grown black woman who believes in the manifesto “Girl, get your money straight” my first response to Beyoncé’s visual album, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/24/beyonce-lemonade-review-a-woman-not-to-be-messed-with">Lemonade</a>, was WOW – this is the business of capitalist money-making at its best.</p><p>Viewers who like to suggest Lemonade was created solely or primarily for black female audiences are missing the point. Commodities, irrespective of their subject matter, are made, produced and marketed to entice any and all consumers. Beyoncé’s audience is the world, and that world of business and money-making has no color.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/may/11/capitalism-of-beyonce-lemonade-album">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>'I never said you should be raped': Azealia Banks apologises to Sarah Palin</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/06/azealia-banks-apologises-to-sarah-palin-twitter</link>
      <description><p>The rapper has apologised to the former governor of Alaska, following an offensive Twitter spree, for her ‘crass New York City sense of humour’</p><p><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/azealia-banks">Azealia Banks</a> has apologised to Sarah Palin for a series of graphic, since deleted tweets which <a href="http://www.people.com/article/sarah-palin-sue-azealia-banks-twitter-rant-apologizes">reportedly</a> led the former governor of Alaska to begin “discussions with attorneys”. </p><p>Banks’s comments were triggered by a <a href="http://www.newslo.com/palin-even-the-french-understand-that-slavery-wasnt-our-fault-because-the-negroes-liked-it/">satirical, made-up news story</a> in which Palin tells an Alaska newspaper that black people “accepted [slavery] willingly” and that “negroes loved being slaves and they were doing just fine under our rules”. The rapper, who did not realise the quotes were fabricated, suggested her audience “find the biggest burliest blackest negroes and let them run a train on her”.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/06/azealia-banks-apologises-to-sarah-palin-twitter">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/azealia-banks">Azealia Banks</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/music/music">Music</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/culture">Culture</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/sarahpalin">Sarah Palin</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/twitter">Twitter</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/race">Race issues</category>
      <pubDate>Wed, 06 Apr 2016 14:17:00 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/06/azealia-banks-apologises-to-sarah-palin-twitter</guid>
      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/149679c1bc30b5303a72d2a0883846c92fa2f801/0_166_5556_3333/master/5556.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=8158be61393b251b4508c1badd6e7657">
        <media:credit scheme="urn:ebu">Photograph: Ross Gilmore/Redferns via Getty Images</media:credit>
      </media:content>
      <media:content width="460" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/149679c1bc30b5303a72d2a0883846c92fa2f801/0_166_5556_3333/master/5556.jpg?w=460&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=719dcd09b0cbbca3e92611ae6468fd15">
        <media:credit scheme="urn:ebu">Photograph: Ross Gilmore/Redferns via Getty Images</media:credit>
      </media:content>
      <dc:creator>Guardian music</dc:creator>

    <item>
      <title>Azealia Banks uses homophobic slur during fracas with flight attendant</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/sep/22/azealia-banks-calls-flight-attendant-homophobic-slur</link>
      <description><p>Video from a New York-to-LA flight shows the rapper, who in since-deleted tweets said she was ‘hit in the face by a man’, playing tug-of-war over her luggage</p><p>Azealia Banks called a flight attendant a homophobic slur while trying to exit a plane on Monday night, a video <a href="http://www.tmz.com/2015/09/22/azealia-banks-flight-homophobic-slur-delta-video/">obtained by TMZ</a> shows.<br></p><p>The rapper was on a flight from New York to LA that landed just before 1am on Tuesday, <a href="http://www.tmz.com/2015/09/22/azealia-banks-flight-homophobic-slur-delta-video/">TMZ reported</a>. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/sep/22/azealia-banks-calls-flight-attendant-homophobic-slur">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/culture">Culture</category>
      <pubDate>Tue, 22 Sep 2015 18:06:01 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/sep/22/azealia-banks-calls-flight-attendant-homophobic-slur</guid>
      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/bd1bb25feff90fa33334f1fee5841fb39d57157c/0_37_2362_1416/master/2362.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=27d1eee59d597e731151f0d1f6e26677">
        <media:credit scheme="urn:ebu">Photograph: Jonny Weeks for the Guardian</media:credit>
      </media:content>
      <media:content width="460" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/bd1bb25feff90fa33334f1fee5841fb39d57157c/0_37_2362_1416/master/2362.jpg?w=460&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=b4b89f0429112e99fce09b1c9a3ff4b1">
        <media:credit scheme="urn:ebu">Photograph: Jonny Weeks for the Guardian</media:credit>
      </media:content>
      <dc:creator>Mahita Gajanan in New York</dc:creator>
